{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2013}} [[File:Holstein dairy cows.jpg|thumb|250px|rBST is a product allowed only in certain jurisdictions and primarily given to [[dairy cattle]] by injection to increase milk production.]] '''Bovine somatotropin''' or '''bovine somatotrophin''' (abbreviated '''bST''' and '''BST'''), or '''bovine growth hormone''' ('''BGH'''), is a [[peptide hormone]] produced by cows' [[pituitary glands]].{{cite web |url=https://extension.usu.edu/files/publications/factsheet/FN-250_6.pdf |title=Bovine Somatotropin in Milk |accessdate=6 March 2011 |author=Charlotte P. Brennand }} Like other hormones, it is produced in small quantities and is used in regulating metabolic processes. After the biotech company [[Genentech]] discovered and patented the gene for BST in the 1970s,Keith Schneider. 10 June 1990. [https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/10/magazine/betting-the-farm-on-biotech.html?pagewanted=all&src=pm "Betting the Farm on Biotech."]. ''the New York Times'' it became possible to synthesize the hormone using [[recombinant DNA technology]] to create '''recombinant bovine somatotropin''' ('''rBST'''), '''recombinant bovine growth hormone''' ('''rBGH'''), or '''artificial growth hormone'''. Four large pharmaceutical companies, [[Monsanto]], [[American Cyanamid]], [[Eli Lilly and Company|Eli Lilly]], and [[Upjohn]], developed commercial rBST products and submitted them to the US [[Food and Drug Administration]] (FDA) for approval.Bijman, J. (1996), "Recombinant Bovine Somatotropin in Europe and the USA." Biotechnology and Development Monitor, No. 27, p. 2-5.[http://www.biotech-monitor.nl/2702.htm]Bovine Somatotropin. Joint FAO/WHO Expert Committee on Food Additives Monograph [ftp://ftp.fao.org/es/esn/jecfa/vetdrug/41-5-bovine_somatotropin.pdf] Monsanto was the first firm to receive approval. Other countries (Mexico, Brazil, India, Russia, and at least ten others) also approved rBST for commercial use.William D. Dobson. June 1996 [http://www.aae.wisc.edu/pubs/sps/pdf/stpap397.pdf The BST Case]. University of Wisconsin-Madison Agricultural and Applied Economics Staff Paper Series No.397 Monsanto licensed Genentech's patent, and marketed their product as "Posilac". In October 2008, Monsanto sold this business, in full, to [[Eli Lilly and Company]] for $300 million plus additional consideration.{{Cite news|url=http://dealbook.blogs.nytimes.com/2008/08/20/eli-lilly-to-buy-monsantos-dairy-cow-hormone-for-300-million/ |title=Eli Lilly to Buy Monsanto's Dairy Cow Hormone for $300 million ‚Äì DealBook Blog |work=The New York Times| date=20 August 2008}} rBST has not been allowed since at least 2000 on the market in Canada, or since 1990 the [[European Union]]. Australia, New Zealand, Japan, Israel and Argentina also banned the use of rBST.{{cn|date=November 2018}} The FDA, [[World Health Organization]], and [[National Institutes of Health]] have independently stated that dairy products and meat from BST-treated cows are safe for human consumption. In the United States, public opinion led some manufacturers and retailers to market only milk that is rBST-free.{{cite news |title=Safeway milk free of bovine hormone |url=http://www.seattlepi.com/business/300596_safeway22.html |work=[[Seattle Post-Intelligencer]] |agency=[[Associated Press]] |date=22 January 2007 |accessdate=4 April 2008}}{{cite web |url=http://www.organicconsumers.org/articles/article_3773.cfm |title=Safeway & Chipotle Chains Dropping Milk & Dairy Derived from Monsanto's Bovine Growth Hormone |last=North |first=R |accessdate=29 January 2008 |date=10 January 2007 |publisher=[[Oregon Physicians for Social Responsibility]]}}{{cite web |publisher=[[Kroger]] |url=http://www.thekrogerco.com/corpnews/corpnewsinfo_pressreleases_08012007.htm |title=Kroger to complete transition to certified rBST-free milk by early 2008 (press release) |year=2007 |accessdate=29 January 2008}}{{cite web |url=http://www.starbucks.com/aboutus/pressdesc.asp?id=819 |title=Statement and Q&A-Starbucks Completes its Conversion ‚Äì All U.S. Company-Operated Stores Use Dairy Sourced Without the Use of rBGH |accessdate=4 April 2008 |publisher=Starbucks Corporation |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080329000803/http://www.starbucks.com/aboutus/pressdesc.asp?id=819 |archivedate=29 March 2008 |df=dmy-all }} A European Union report on the animal welfare effects of rBST states that its use often results in "severe and unnecessary pain, suffering and distress" for cows, "associated with serious [[Mastitis in dairy cattle|mastitis]], foot disorders and some reproductive problems".{{Cite book | title = Report on Animal Welfare Aspects of the Use of Bovine Somatotrophin | url = http://ec.europa.eu/food/fs/sc/scah/out21_en.pdf | format = PDF | date = 10 March 1999 | accessdate = 16 January 2008 | publisher = The Scientific Committee on Animal Health and Animal Welfare, [[European Union]]. | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080904003449/http://ec.europa.eu/food/fs/sc/scah/out21_en.pdf | archivedate = 4 September 2008 | df = dmy-all }}
Note: According to the report, somatotropine, which is often used, is a misnomer as "tropic factors affect direction or extent of body movement while trophic factors affect growth". So the Commission uses the spelling somatotrophin. ==History== [[File:Somatotropine.GIF|thumb|right|250px|Image of peptide somatotropine.]] {{Expand section|1=discussion of development efforts by Lilly, American Cyanamid, and Upjohn|date=September 2012}} In 1937, the administration of BST was shown to increase the milk yield in [[lactation|lactating]] cows by preventing mammary cell death in dairy cattle. Until the 1980s, use of the compound was very limited in agriculture as the sole source of the hormone was from bovine carcasses. During this time, the knowledge of the structure and function of the hormone increased.{{cite web | title = Dairy Research and Bovine Somatotropin | url = http://www.extension.umn.edu/distribution/livestocksystems/DI6337.html | publisher = [[University of Minnesota]] | last = Crooker | first = BA | year = 1993 |accessdate=16 January 2008 | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070618015651/http://www.extension.umn.edu/distribution/livestocksystems/DI6337.html| archivedate = 18 June 2007|display-authors=etal}} With the advent of [[biotechnology]], one of the pioneering biotech companies, [[Genentech]], in 1981 succeeded in cloning and patenting the gene for BST.{{cite web|url=http://www.google.com/patents/US4880910 |title=US Patent 4880910 |publisher=Google.com |date=}} [[Monsanto]] had been working along the same lines and struck a deal with Genentech in 1979 to license Genentech's patents and collaborate on development of a [[Recombinant DNA|recombinant]] version of BST ‚Äì a process on which Monsanto would invest $300 million. The two companies used [[genetic engineering]] to clone the BST gene into ''[[Escherichia coli|E. coli]]''. The bacteria are grown in [[bioreactors]], then broken up and separated from the rBST, which is purified to produce the injectable hormone. They published their first field trial results in 1981.{{cite journal | last1 = Bauman | first1 = D.E. | year = 1999 | title = Bovine somatotropin and lactation: from basic science to commercial application | url = http://www.ansci.cornell.edu/bauman/envir_impact/BaumanDomAnEndo.pdf | format = PDF | journal = Domestic Animal Endocrinology | volume = 17 | issue = | pages = 101‚Äì116 | pmid = 10527114 | doi = 10.1016/s0739-7240(99)00028-4 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20120616043549/http://www.ansci.cornell.edu/bauman/envir_impact/BaumanDomAnEndo.pdf | archivedate = 16 June 2012 | df = dmy-all }}{{cite journal | last1 = Peel | first1 = CJ | display-authors = 1 | last2 = et al | date = Sep 1981 | title = Effect of exogenous growth hormone on lactational performance in high yielding dairy cows | url = | journal = J Nutr | volume = 111 | issue = 9| pages = 1662‚Äì71 | pmid = 7277044 }}{{Cite journal|last=Bauman|first=Dale E.|date=1992-12-01|title=Bovine Somatotropin: Review of an Emerging Animal Technology1|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0022030292781193|journal=Journal of Dairy Science|volume=75|issue=12|pages=3432‚Äì3451|doi=10.3168/jds.S0022-0302(92)78119-3|pmid=1474210}} Lilly, American Cyanamid, Upjohn, and Monsanto all submitted applications to market rBST to the U.S. FDA, and the FDA completed its review of the human safety component of these applications in 1986 and found food from rBST-treated cows to be safe; however, strong public concern led to calls for more studies, investigations, and public discussions, which included an unprecedented conference on the safety of rBST in 1990 organized by the [[National Institutes of Health]] at the request of Sen. [[Patrick Leahy]].{{cite web|url=http://oig.hhs.gov/oas/reports/phs/c9000046.pdf|title=Auditor's Report|author=|date=|website=HHS.gov|access-date=10 May 2017}} FDA approved Monsanto's application in 1993.{{cite web|url=http://www.fda.gov/AnimalVeterinary/SafetyHealth/ProductSafetyInformation/ucm055435.htm |title=FDA page on BST |publisher=FDA.gov |date= }} Monsanto launched rBST, brand-named Posilac, in 1994.{{cite web | url = http://www.monsantodairy.com/about/general_info/index.html | title = General information ‚Äì Posilac |access-date=16 January 2008 | year = 2007 | publisher = Monsanto | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080101123956/http://www.monsantodairy.com/about/general_info/index.html| archivedate = 1 January 2008}} ==Mechanism of action== An average dairy cow begins her lactation with a moderate daily level{{Clarify|reason=vague|date=May 2017}} of milk production. This daily output increases until, at about 70 days into the lactation, production peaks. From that time until the cow is dry, production slowly decreases. This increase and decrease in production is partially caused by the count of milk-producing cells in the udder. Cell counts begin at a moderate number,{{Clarify|reason=vague|date=May 2017}} increase during the first part of the lactation, then decrease as the lactation proceeds. Once lost, these cells generally do not regrow until the next lactation. Administration of rBST or BST prior to peak production, in cows that are well fed, slows the rate at which the number of mammary cells decreases, and increases the amount of nutrients directed away from fat and toward the mammary cells, leading to an extension of peak milk production. The effects are mediated by the [[insulin-like growth factor]] (IGF) system, which is upregulated in response to BST or rBST administration in well-fed cows.{{cite web | url = http://www.monsantodairy.com/faqs/fda_rbst.html | title= bST Fact Sheet | last = Barbano | first = D | publisher = Monsanto |access-date=16 January 2008 | year = 2007| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20071224141534/http://www.monsantodairy.com/faqs/fda_rbst.html| archivedate = 24 December 2007}} ==Use on farms== From 2000 to 2005, the USDA National Agricultural Statistics Service survey of dairy producers found that about 17% of producers used rBST.Gillespie J et al (2010) [http://www.agbioforum.org/v13n3/v13n3a04-gillespie.pdf Adoption of Recombinant Bovine Somatotropin and Farm Profitability: Does Farm Size Matter?] AgBioForum, 13(3): 251-262. The 2010 USDA National Agricultural Statistics Service survey of Wisconsin farms found that about 18% of dairy farms used rBST.Staff, USDA National Agricultural Statistics Service 2010. [http://www.nass.usda.gov/Statistics_by_State/Wisconsin/Publications/Dairy/Dairy_OP_Release_10.pdf 2010 Dairy Producer Survey] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120302125728/http://www.nass.usda.gov/Statistics_by_State/Wisconsin/Publications/Dairy/Dairy_OP_Release_10.pdf |date=2 March 2012 }} === Role in synchronized fertilization on dairy farms === By using cows that produce offspring within a one to two week period, synchronized breeding allows dairy farmers to artificially inseminate cows for maximum pregnancy rates with minimal effort.{{cite web|last1=DeJarnette|first1=Mel|title=OVSYNCH, CO-SYNCH, PRESYNCH and KITCHENSYNCH: How did breeding cows get so complicated?|url=http://www.selectsires.com/programs/docs/ovsynch_cosynch_presynch.pdf?version=20161206|website=Select Sires|publisher=Select Sires Inc.}} Bovine somatotropin is a [[placental lactogen]] (PL) hormone and falls under the class of growth hormone, or somatotropin. It is relevant to the practice of artificially expediting placental development in farm mammals, specifically dairy cattle. The mechanism through which the hormones of this somatotropin exert their effects can be observed at the cellular and molecular level in placental tissue. For mammals exposed to the hormone, bovine somatotropin associates with [[N-linked glycosylation|N-glycosylated]] proteins that are heavily involved in placental gestation. Knowledge of this and how BT works in conjunction with growth hormones allows for agricultural researchers to experiment on the effects of synchronization in farm animals.{{Cite web|url=http://extension.uga.edu/publications/detail.cfm?number=B1227|title=Dairy Herd Synchronization Programs {{!}} Publications {{!}} UGA Extension|website=extension.uga.edu|access-date=2016-12-10}} Synchronization involves treating cattle with a dose of BsT before artificially inseminating them, according to a fixed interval schedule. Synchronization and bST treatment may be used to increase first-service pregnancy rates while following this timed artificial insemination protocol. This would therefore allow agricultural researchers to observe the effects of hormones in relation to natural estrous cycles. Dairy cattle experienced increased rates of pregnancy during synchronization when exposed to BsT. The effects of BsT on this treatment are dependent on the step in the estrous cycle, seeing how BsT has a stimulatory effect of progesterone on the corpus luteum.{{Cite journal|last=Lopes|first=Fernanda|title=Effects of Presynchronization and Bovine Somatotropin on Pregnancy Rates to a Timed Artificial Insemination Protocol in Lactating Dairy Cows|url=https://www.academia.edu/8285143/Effects_of_Presynchronization_and_Bovine_Somatotropin_on_Pregnancy_Rates_to_a_Timed_Artificial_Insemination_Protocol_in_Lactating_Dairy_Cows|journal=Journal of Dairy Science|doi=10.3168/jds.s0022-0302(01)74600-0|volume=84|year=2001|pages=1646‚Äì1659}} ==Controversy== Though approved by the FDA in 1993, rBST has been immersed in controversy since the early 1980s. Part of the controversy concerns potential effects on [[animal health]] and [[human health]]. ===Animal health=== One [[meta-analysis]] published in 2003 suggested a negative impact of rBST's effects on bovine health.{{cite journal |pmid=14620861 |year=2003 |last1=Dohoo |first1=IR |last2=Desc√¥teaux |first2=L |last3=Leslie |first3=K |last4=Fredeen |first4=A |last5=Shewfelt |first5=W |last6=Preston |first6=A |last7=Dowling |first7=P |title=A meta-analysis review of the effects of recombinant bovine somatotropin. 2. Effects on animal health, reproductive performance, and culling |volume=67 |issue=4 |pages=252‚Äì64 |pmc=280709 |journal=Canadian journal of veterinary research}} Findings suggested an average increase in milk output ranging from 11%‚Äì16%, an approximate 24% increase in the risk of clinical [[Mastitis in dairy cattle|mastitis]], a 40% reduction in fertility, and 55% increased risk of developing clinical signs of [[lameness (equine)|lameness]]. The same study reported a decrease in body condition score for cows treated with rBST, though an increase in their dry matter intake occurred. Another meta-analysis (2003) reported on body condition scores (BCS) but could not reach a conclusion due to lack of homogeneity in study design and reporting. They found a trend towards decreased BCS in treated cows but state "Depending on the level of body condition in these cows, this effect may have been beneficial or detrimental." {{cite journal |pmid=14620860 |year=2003 |last1=Dohoo |first1=IR |last2=Leslie |first2=K |last3=Desc√¥teaux |first3=L |last4=Fredeen |first4=A |last5=Dowling |first5=P |last6=Preston |first6=A |last7=Shewfelt |first7=W |title=A meta-analysis review of the effects of recombinant bovine somatotropin. 1. Methodology and effects on production |volume=67 |issue=4 |pages=241‚Äì51 |pmc=280708 |journal=Canadian journal of veterinary research}} This analysis did not report on clinical mastitis. A more recent meta-analysis (2014) published by the Journal of the [[American Veterinary Medical Association]] showed no significant increase in risk of clinical [[Mastitis in dairy cattle|mastitis]] nor other adverse effects on cow health and well-being. This review included 26 peer-reviewed studies that involved the use of the rBST-Zn formulation available to US producers in accordance with the label instructions for treatment initiation (57 to 70 days postpartum), dose (500 mg, q 14 d), and route (SC).{{Cite journal|last=St-Pierre|first=Normand R.|last2=Milliken|first2=George A.|last3=Bauman|first3=Dale E.|last4=Collier|first4=Robert J.|last5=Hogan|first5=Joseph S.|last6=Shearer|first6=Jan K.|last7=Smith|first7=K. Larry|last8=Thatcher|first8=William W.|date=2014-08-22|title=Meta-analysis of the effects of sometribove zinc suspension on the production and health of lactating dairy cows|url=http://avmajournals.avma.org/doi/abs/10.2460/javma.245.5.550|journal=Journal of the American Veterinary Medical Association|volume=245|issue=5|pages=550‚Äì564|doi=10.2460/javma.245.5.550|issn=0003-1488|pmid=25148097}} Mastitis has cost American dairy industries an estimated $1.5 to 2 billion per year in treating dairy cows.{{Cite journal|title = The National Mastitis Council: A Global Organization for Mastitis Control and Milk Quality, 50 Years and Beyond|url = https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s10911-014-9328-6|journal = Journal of Mammary Gland Biology and Neoplasia|date = 2014-12-19|issn = 1083-3021|pages = 241‚Äì251|volume = 19|issue = 3‚Äì4|doi = 10.1007/s10911-014-9328-6|language = en|first = John R.|last = Middleton|first2 = Anne|last2 = Saeman|first3 = Larry K.|last3 = Fox|first4 = Jason|last4 = Lombard|first5 = Joe S.|last5 = Hogan|first6 = K. Larry|last6 = Smith}} [[File:Mamite √• grangrin vatche p√©s fritches.jpg|thumb|250px|One meta-analysis suggested that the use of rBST increases health problems with cows, including [[Mastitis in dairy cattle|mastitis]].]] In 1994, a European Union scientific commission was asked to report on the incidence of mastitis and other disorders in dairy cows and on other aspects of their welfare. The commission's statement, subsequently adopted by the European Union, stated that the use of rBST substantially increased health problems with cows, including foot problems, mastitis, and injection site reactions, impinged on the welfare of the animals, and caused reproductive disorders. The report concluded, on the basis of the health and welfare of the animals, rBST should not be used. [[Health Canada]] prohibited the sale of rBST in 1999; the external committees found, although there was no significant health risk to humans, the drug presents a threat to animal health, and, for this reason, cannot be sold in Canada.{{cite web | url = http://www.hc-sc.gc.ca/ahc-asc/media/nr-cp/1999/1999_03_e.html | website = [[Health Canada]] | title = Health Canada rejects bovine growth hormone in Canada | date = 14 January 1999 |accessdate=16 January 2008 | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080110050349/http://www.hc-sc.gc.ca/ahc-asc/media/nr-cp/1999/1999_03_e.html| archivedate = 10 January 2008}} Monsanto-sponsored trials reviewed by the FDA asked whether the use of rBST makes cows more susceptible to mastitis.{{cite web | url = http://consumersunion.org/news/potential-public-health-impacts-of-the-use-of-recombinant-bovine-somatotropin-in-dairy-production-part-1/ |title = Potential Public Health Impacts Of The Use Of Recombinant Bovine Somatotropin In Dairy Production | date = September 1997 |last1=Hansen |first1=Michael, Ph.D. |last2=Halloran |first2=Jean M. |last3=Groth |first3=Edward III, Ph.D. |last4=Lefferts |first4=Lisa Y.}} According to the FDA, which used data from eight Monsanto-sponsored trials in its decision in 1993 to approve Monsanto's rBST product, the answer is yes. The data from these eight trials, which involved 487 cows, showed that during the period of rBST treatment, mastitis incidence increased by 76% in [[primiparous]] cows and by 50% for multiparous cows. Overall, the increase was 53%. Conversely, however a study from the University of Georgia on the monitoring post-approval of rBST, showed that there was no statistically significant (P>0.05) derivation in cases of clinical mastitis in dairy cows treated with rBST.{{Cite web|url=http://www.ads.uga.edu/documents/relationshipbetweentheuseofrecombinantbovinesomatotropinposilacindairycowsandtheincidenceofc.pdf|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151010092939/http://www.ads.uga.edu/documents/relationshipbetweentheuseofrecombinantbovinesomatotropinposilacindairycowsandtheincidenceofc.pdf|dead-url=yes|archive-date=10 October 2015|title=Relationship between the Use of Recombinant Bovine Somatotropin (Posilac¬Æ) in Dairy Cows and the Incidence of Clinical Mastitis|last=McClary|first=David|date=21 December 2010|website=|publisher=University of Georgia Agriculture|access-date=18 December 2016|df=dmy-all}} ====Macronutrient composition==== The overall composition of the milk including the fat, protein, and lactose content is not altered substantially by the use of rBST in dairy cows. The milk may have a slight change in fat content within the first few weeks of rBST treatment as the cow is allowed to adjust her metabolism and feed intake. The changes in the fat content have been shown to be temporary. The composition of the milk has been examined in more than 200 different experiments. Natural variation within milk is normal with or without rBST treatment in cows due to genetics, location, feed, age, and other environmental factors. Protein in milk content has also been studied and was shown to have no apparent change in rBST treated cows. The vitamins and minerals that are normally in milk were also unaltered in milk from rBST treated cows. Freezing point, pH, thermal properties, and other manufacturing characteristics of milk were shown to be the same regardless of whether it came from rBST treated cows or not.{{cite journal|last1=Collier|first1=R. J.|last2=Bauman|first2=D. E.|title=Update on human health concerns of recombinant bovine somatotropin use in dairy cows|journal=Journal of Animal Science|date=1 April 2014|volume=92|issue=4|pages=1800‚Äì1807|doi=10.2527/jas.2013-7383|pmid=24663163|issn=1525-3163}} ====Hormones==== BST is destroyed in the digestive system and even if directly injected, has not been found to have any direct effect on humans. Researchers have found that "IGF-1 in milk is not denatured by pasteurization and the extent to which intact, active IGF-1 is absorbed through the human digestive tract remains still however uncertain" implicating that an extensive study on the nature of IGF-1 in relation to rBST milk is required.{{Cite journal|title = Analytical strategies to detect use of recombinant bovine somatotropin in food-producing animals|url = http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0165993613002306|journal = TrAC Trends in Analytical Chemistry|date = 2014-01-01|pages = 1‚Äì10|volume = 53|doi = 10.1016/j.trac.2013.08.006|first = G.|last = Dervilly-Pinel|first2 = S.|last2 = Pr√©vost|first3 = F.|last3 = Monteau|first4 = B.|last4 = Le Bizec}} FDA rBST labeling guidelines state, "FDA is concerned that the term 'rbST free' may imply a compositional difference between milk from treated and untreated cows rather than a difference in the way the milk is produced. Without proper context, such statements could be misleading. Such unqualified statements may imply that milk from untreated cows is safer or of higher quality than milk from treated cows. Such an implication would be false and misleading".{{cite web |url=http://www.grist.org/article/food-2010-10-06-court-rules-on-rbgh-free-milk |title=Court Rules rBGH-Free Milk *Is* Better than the Kind Produced with Artificial Hormones. Now What? |accessdate=6 October 2010 |quote= |publisher=Grist }} The FDA World Health Organization, and [[National Institutes of Health]] have independently stated that dairy products and meat from rBST-treated cows are safe for human consumption. The American Cancer Society issued a report declaring, "The evidence for potential harm to humans [from rBGH milk] is inconclusive. It is not clear that drinking milk produced using rBGH significantly increases IGF-1 levels in humans or adds to the risk of developing cancer. More research is needed to help better address these concerns."Staff, American Cancer Society. Last Medical Review: 18 February 2011; Last Revised: 18 February 2011. [http://www.cancer.org/cancer/cancercauses/othercarcinogens/athome/recombinant-bovine-growth-hormone Recombinant Bovine Growth Hormone] ===Human health=== The effects of rBGH on human health is an ongoing debate, in part due to the lack of conclusive evidence. A few of the most debated issues include: [[IGF-1]] is a hormone found in humans that is responsible for growth promotion, protein synthesis, and insulin actions over the lifecycle. The hormone has been shown to influence the growth of tumors in some studies and may be linked to the development of prostate,{{cite journal | last1 = Allen | first1 = NE | last2 = Key | first2 = TJ | last3 = Appleby | first3 = PN | display-authors = 3 | last4 = et al | year = 2007 | title = Serum insulin-like growth factor (IGF)-I and IGF-binding protein-3 concentrations and prostate cancer risk: Results from the European Prospective Investigation into Cancer and Nutrition | url = | journal = Cancer Epidemiol Biomarkers Prev | volume = 16 | issue = | pages = 1121‚Äì1127 |pmid=17548673|doi=10.1158/1055-9965.EPI-06-1062}}{{open access}} colorectal, breast,{{cite journal | last1 = Hankinson | first1 = SE | last2 = Schernhammer | first2 = ES | year = 2003 | title = Insulin-like growth factor and breast cancer risk: Evidence from observational studies | journal = Breast Dis. | volume = 17 | issue = | pages = 27‚Äì40 |pmid=15687675| doi=10.3233/bd-2003-17104}}{{cite journal | last1 = Rinaldi | first1 = S | last2 = Peeters | first2 = PH | last3 = Berrino | first3 = F | display-authors = 3 | last4 = et al | year = 2006 | title = IGF-I, IGFBP-3 and breast cancer risk in women: The European Prospective Investigation into Cancer and Nutrition (EPIC) | url = | journal = Endocr Relat Cancer | volume = 13 | issue = | pages = 593‚Äì615 | doi=10.1677/erc.1.01150}} and other cancers.{{cite journal | last1 = Giovannucci | first1 = E | year = 2003 | title = Nutrition, insulin, insulin-like growth factors and cancer | url = | journal = Hormone & Metabolic Research | volume = 35 | issue = | pages = 694‚Äì704 | doi=10.1055/s-2004-814147}}{{cite journal | last1 = Furstenberger | first1 = G | last2 = Senn | first2 = HJ | year = 2002 | title = Insulin-like growth factors and cancer | url = | journal = Lancet Oncol | volume = 3 | issue = | pages = 298‚Äì302 | doi=10.1016/s1470-2045(02)00731-3}}{{cite journal | last1 = Giovannucci | first1 = E | last2 = Pollak | first2 = M | last3 = Liu | first3 = Y | display-authors = 3 | last4 = et al | year = 2003 | title = Nutritional predictors of insulin-like growth factor I and their relationships to cancer in men | url = | journal = Cancer Epidemiol Biomarkers Prev | volume = 12 | issue = | pages = 84‚Äì89 }} IGF-1 is also found in milk. Previous research has proposed an increase of IGF-1 in rBST-treated cows, but this claim is currently not substantiated. In addition, no current evidence shows that orally consumed IGF-1 is absorbed in humans and the dietary amount is negligible when compared to what the body produces on its own. "IGF-1 in milk is not denatured (inactivated) by pasteurization. The extent to which intact, active IGF-1 is absorbed through the human digestive tract remains uncertain. The American Cancer Society has reviewed the evidence concerning IGF-1 in milk from rBST-treated cows, and found that: "While there may be a link between IGF-1 blood levels and cancer, the exact nature of this link remains unclear. Some studies have shown that adults who drink milk have about 10% higher levels of IGF-1 in their blood than those who drink little or no milk. But this same finding has also been reported in people who drink soymilk. This suggests that the increase in IGF-1 may not be specific to cow's milk, and may be caused by protein, minerals, or some other factors in milk unrelated to rBGH. There have been no direct comparisons of IGF-1 levels in people who drink ordinary cow's milk vs. milk stimulated by rBGH. At this time, it is not clear that drinking milk, produced with or without rBGH treatment, increases blood IGF-1 levels into a range that might be of concern regarding cancer risk or other health effects. IGF-1 concentrations are slightly higher (to variable degrees, depending on the study) in milk from cows treated with rBGH than in untreated milk. This variability is presumed to be much less than the normal range of variation of IGF-1 in cow's milk due to natural factors, but more research is needed." Research is supportive of milk supplying vital nutrients used in childhood development.https://medical.gerber.com/nutrition-health-topics/infant-early-childhood-nutrition/articles/early-childhood-nutrition-toddlers-to-preschoolers As of 2014, evidence does not link rBST-treated milk with adverse health outcomes for children. Several studies have looked at the relationship between type 1 diabetes and infant feeding. Environmental triggers that may elicit an autoimmune reaction is the mechanism in which is being studied. Some studies have shown early exposure to bovine milk may predispose an infant to type 1 diabetes, whereas other studies show no causality.{{cite web|title=Health Concerns about Dairy Products|url=http://www.pcrm.org/health/diets/vegdiets/health-concerns-about-dairy-products|website=The Physicians Committee|language=en|date=13 October 2010}} The American Society of Animal Science published an article in 2014 after reviewing health issues arising from the rBST debate. The article indicated "there are no new human health issues related to the use of rbST by the dairy industry. Use of rbST has no effect on the micro- and macrocomposition of milk. Also, no evidence exists that rbST use has increased human exposure to antibiotic residues in milk. Concerns that IGF-I present in milk could have biological effects on humans have been allayed by studies showing that oral consumption of IGF-I by humans has little or no biological activity. Additionally, concentrations of IGF-I in digestive tract fluids of humans far exceed any IGF-I consumed when drinking milk. Furthermore, chronic supplementation of cows with rbST does not increase concentrations of milk IGF-I outside the range typically observed for effects of farm, parity, or stage of lactation. Use of rbST has not affected expression of retroviruses in cattle or posed an increased risk to human health from retroviruses in cattle. Furthermore, risk for development of type 1 or type 2 diabetes has not increased in children or adults consuming milk and dairy products from rbST-supplemented cows. Overall, milk and dairy products provide essential nutrients and related benefits in health maintenance and the prevention of chronic diseases." {{cite journal | last1 = Collier | first1 = R. J. | last2 = Bauman | first2 = D. E. | year = 2014 | title = Update on human health concerns of recombinant bovine somatotropin use in dairy cows | url = | journal = Journal of Animal Science | volume = 92 | issue = 4| pages = 1800‚Äì1807 | doi = 10.2527/jas.2013-7383 | pmid=24663163}} Keeping in mind that bovine somatropin is a protein growth hormone, it can increase average milk yield anywhere from 10 to 15%, which in turn would lead to cows consuming substantially more nutrients in order to keep up with the increased milk production. Most of a cow's energy consumption goes directly towards milk production. In certain areas of the world, like Ethiopia where this was studied extensively, as the cows needed to intake more nutrition to balance out their milk production, there was also an increased level of chemical fertilizers and heavy metal traces found in the milk due to increased exposure to agricultural chemicals. These chemicals can then easily be passed on to humans and lead to a contaminated milk supply. BST increases the longevity or the activity of the mammary cell leading to higher milk production and some other non-desirable side effects.{{Cite journal|last=Centner|first=Terence J.|date=2016-09-01|title=Efforts to slacken antibiotic resistance: Labeling meat products from animals raised without antibiotics in the United States|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0048969716310130|journal=Science of the Total Environment|volume=563‚Äì564|pages=1088‚Äì1094|doi=10.1016/j.scitotenv.2016.05.082}} Despite public controversy of the use of growth hormones in food-producing animals, the number of violations has decreased substantially in the past two decades.{{When|date=May 2017}} For comparison, the level of rBST detected in bulk milk tank trucks in 2012 was one fifth the level that it was in 1996. As reported by the USDA, the US pattern for milk BTSCC declined steadily from 316.000 cells per mL of milk in 2001 to 224,000 cells/mL in 2010 and 206,000 cells/mL in 2011 (USDA, 2013). Mammary health in the animals themselves has improved over this time period as well as the overall health of the dairy herd in general. This is mostly attributed to better application methods of rBST and a better understanding of how the hormone affects the animals.{{cite conference |url=http://hdl.handle.net/1813/37969 |title=An Update On rBST - Human Safety And Animal Efficiency And Welfare |last1=Bauman |first1=D.E.|last2=Collier |first2=R.J.|date=2014|conference= Cornell Nutrition Conference for Feed Manufacturers}} ===Environmental impact=== On an industry level, supplementing one million cows with rBST would result in the same amount of milk produced using 157,000 fewer cows.{{cite journal|last1=Capper|first1=J. L.|last2=Castaneda-Gutierrez|first2=E.|last3=Cady|first3=R. A.|last4=Bauman|first4=D. E.|title=The environmental impact of recombinant bovine somatotropin (rbST) use in dairy production|journal=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences|date=30 June 2008|volume=105|issue=28|pages=9668‚Äì9673|doi=10.1073/pnas.0802446105|pmid=18591660|pmc=2442129}} Farmers are, therefore, able to improve milk production with a smaller dairy population. Some studies show that rBST-treated cows reduce the impact of greenhouse gases in comparison with conventional and organic dairy operations, however, it must be noted that the lead of the project, Roger Cady, was linked to Monsanto's rBST department.https://www.organicconsumers.org/news/deconstructing-monsantos-propaganda-bovine-growth-hormone-will-reduce-global-warming Cady's study showed that excretion of nitrogen and phosphorus, two major environmental pollutants arising from animal agriculture, was reduced by 9.1 and 11.8%, respectively.{{cite journal | last1 = Capper | first1 = JL | display-authors = 1 | last2 = et al | date = Jul 2008 | title = The environmental impact of recombinant bovine somatotropin (rbST) use in dairy production | journal = Proc Natl Acad Sci U S A | volume = 105 | issue = 28| pages = 9668‚Äì73 | doi = 10.1073/pnas.0802446105 | pmid = 18591660 | pmc=2442129}} Carbon dioxide is recognized to be the most important anthropogenic greenhouse gas,Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change. [http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/publications_ipcc_fourth_assessment_report_wg1_report_the_physical_science_basis.htm IPCC Fourth Assessment Report (AR4) Climate Change 2007: The Physical Science Basis] and livestock metabolism and fossil fuel consumption are the main sources of emissions from animal agriculture. * Livestock metabolism-use of rBST in lactating cows decreases the quantity of energy and protein needed in comparison to conventional dairy operations along with reducing the total feedstuff used. * Fossil fuel consumption-targets atmospheric pollution and resource sustainability environmental concerns. With cows treated with rBST, producing a higher milk yield reduces the feed requirement which in turn decreases with electricity for milk production and the energy required from fossil fuels for cropping. In addition, the global warming potential is reduced equivalent to removing 400,000 family cars from the road. When conventional, conventional with rBST, and organic dairy operations are compared, 8% fewer cows are needed in an rBST-supplemented population, whereas organic production systems require a 25% increase to meet production targets. This is due to a lower milk yield per cow due to the pasture-based system which is attributed with a greater maintenance energy expenditure associated with grazing behavior.Subcommittee on Dairy Cattle Nutrition; Committee on Animal Nutrition; Board on Agriculture and Natural Resources (BANR); Division on Earth and Life Studies (DELS); National Research Council [http://www.nap.edu/openbook.php?isbn=0309069971 Nutrient Requirements of Dairy Cattle: Seventh Revised Edition. National Academies Press, 2001]{{rp|20‚Äì21}} ===Lawsuit against WTVT=== In 1997, the news division of [[WTVT]] (Channel 13), a [[Fox Television Stations Group|Fox-owned station]] in [[Tampa, Florida]], planned to air an investigative report by [[Steve Wilson (reporter)|Steve Wilson]] and [[Jane Akre]] on the health risks associated with Monsanto's bovine growth hormone product, Posilac.{{cite web|url=http://www.sptimes.com/News/081900/TampaBay/Reporter_wins_suit_ov.shtml |title=Reporter wins suit over firing |publisher=SPTimes.com |date=19 August 2000 |access-date=28 October 2011}} Just before the story was to air, Fox received a letter from Monsanto saying the reporters were biased and that the story would damage the company. Akre stated that Wilson and she went through 83 rewrites over eight months.''Deconstructing Supper''. Dir. Marianne Kaplan. Prod. Leonard Terhoch & Marianne Kaplan. 2002. VHS. Retrieved 2011-11-24. (23-minute mark.) Negotiations broke down and both reporters were eventually fired. Wilson and Akre alleged the firing was for retaliation, while WTVT contended they were fired for insubordination. The reporters then sued Fox/WTVT in Florida state court under the state's [[whistleblower]] statute. In 2000, a Florida jury found that while no evidence showed Fox/WTVT had bowed to any pressure from Monsanto to alter the story, Akre, but not Wilson, was a whistleblower and was unjustly fired. She was awarded a $425,000 settlement. At the time of the decision, "the station claimed it did not bend to Monsanto's letter and wanted to air a hard-hitting story with a number of statements critical of Monsanto." Fox appealed the decision stating that under Florida law, a whistleblower can only act if "a law, rule, or regulation" has been broken and argued that the FCC's policy against distortions or misrepresentations presented as news did not fit that definition.{{cite web|url=https://caselaw.findlaw.com/fl-district-court-of-appeal/1310807.html |title=NEW WORLD COMMUNICATIONS OF TAMPA INC WTVT TV v. AKRE, No. 2D01-529., February 14, 2003 ‚Äì FL District Court of Appeal | FindLaw |publisher=Caselaw.findlaw.com |date= }} On 14 February 2003, the appeals court overturned the verdict, finding that Akre was not a whistleblower because of the Florida "legislature's requirement that agency statements that fit the definition of a "rule" (must) be formally adopted (rules). Recognizing an uncodified agency policy developed through the adjudicative process as the equivalent of a formally adopted rule is not consistent with this policy, and it would expand the scope of conduct that could subject an employer to liability beyond what Florida's Legislature could have contemplated when it enacted the whistle-blower's statute." ==Regulation== Use of the recombinant supplement has been controversial.{{cite article url=http://www.agbioforum.org/v3n23/v3n23a14-collier.htm title=Regulation Of rbST In The US author=Robert Collier journal=AgBioForum volume=3 year=2000 pages=156-163 }}[https://sencanada.ca/en/Content/SEN/Committee/361/agri/27eva-e "Proceedings of the Standing Senate Committee on Agriculture and Forestry Issue 27 - Evidence for the morning sitting OTTAWA, Monday, December 7, 1998"] The assessment of the United States FDA is that there is no significant difference between milk from treated and untreated cows.FDA Analysis of DGXXIV Report on Public Health Aspects of BST. [http://www.fda.gov/AnimalVeterinary/NewsEvents/CVMUpdates/ucm130353.htm Link.] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120210082627/http://www.fda.gov/AnimalVeterinary/NewsEvents/CVMUpdates/ucm130353.htm |date=10 February 2012 }} Twenty-one other countries have also approved marketing of rBST: Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Ecuador, Egypt, Guatemala, Honduras, Jamaica, Lebanon, Mexico, Panama, Paraguay, Peru, Salvador, South Africa, South Korea, Uruguay and Venezuela. However, regulatory bodies in several countries, such as the Canada, Japan, Pakistan, Australia, New Zealand, and Argentina, along with the Euopean Union, rejected Monsanto's application to sell rBST[http://europa.eu/rapid/pressReleasesAction.do?reference=IP/99/798&format=HTML&aged=0&language=EN&guiLanguage=en europa.eu: "Commission proposes ban on BST."], press release IP/99/978. because rBST increases the risk of health problems in cows, including clinical mastitis, reduced fertility, and reduced body condition.Horovitz, Bruce. [https://www.usatoday.com/money/industries/food/2009-03-15-dairy-growth-hormone-ban_N.htm Companies cut synthetic hormone from dairy products], ''USA Today'', 16 March 2009. Retrieved 20 May 2009. In Canada, bulk milk products from the United States that have been produced with rBST are still allowed to be sold and used in food manufacture (cheese, yogurt, etc.) due to holes in the ingredient labelling system.[http://publications.gc.ca/collections/Collection-R/LoPBdP/BP/prb981-e.htm Parliamentary Research Branch: "RECOMBINANT BOVINE SOMATOTROPIN (rbST)"] PRB 98-1E, prepared by: Fr√©d√©ric Forge Science and Technology Division October 1998 Revised 11 August 1999 In 1990, the European Union placed a moratorium on its sale by all member nations. It was turned into a permanent ban starting from 1 January 2000; the decision was based solely on veterinary concerns, laws, and treaties.{{cite web|url=http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=CELEX:31999D0879:EN:HTML |title=European Council Decision of December 17, 1999 |publisher=Eur-lex.europa.eu |date= }} An in-depth report published in 1999 analysed in detail the various human health risks associated with rBST.{{cite web| title=Report on Public Health Aspects of the Use of Bovine Somatotrophin|url=http://ec.europa.eu/food/fs/sc/scv/out19_en.html|year=1999}} Canada's health board, [[Health Canada]], refused to approve rBST for use on Canadian dairies, citing concerns over animal health. The study found the occurrence of an antibody reaction, possible hypersensitivity, in a subchronic (90-day) study of rbST oral toxicity in rats that resulted in one test animal's developing an antibody response at low dose (0.1 mg/kg/day) after 14 weeks. However, the board stated, with the exception of concerns raised regarding hypersensitivity, "the panel finds no biologically plausible reason for concern about human safety if rBST were to be approved for sale in Canada."{{cite web|url=http://www.hc-sc.gc.ca/dhp-mps/vet/issues-enjeux/rbst-stbr/rep_rcpsc-rap_crmcc_e.html |title=Executive Summary ‚Äì Report of the Royal College of Physicians and Surgeons of Canada Expert Panel on Human safety of rBST |publisher=Hc-sc.gc.ca |date=21 August 2009 }} The [[Codex Alimentarius]] Commission, a United Nations body that sets international food standards, has, as of 2017, refused to approve rBST as safe. The Codex Alimentarius does not have authority to ban or approve the hormone, but its decisions are regarded as a standard and approval by the Codex would have allowed exporting countries to challenge countries with a ban on rBST before the [[World Trade Organization]].{{cite web|url=http://www.foxbghsuit.com/codex063099.htm |title=International Health Group Shuns Bgh |publisher=Foxbghsuit.com |date=3 July 1999 |access-date=}} === Abuse on dairy farms === Recombinant bovine somatotropin is an artificially synthesized form of the bovine growth hormone. It is legal for use as an artificial cattle lactation stimulant in several countries, including the US. However, its use is prohibited in most of Europe for reasons of consumer preference, animal well-being, and skepticism of new technology.{{cite web|last1=Bauman|first1=Dale E.|title=Facts about Recombinant Bovine Somatotropin (rbST)|url=https://ansci.cals.cornell.edu/sites/ansci.cals.cornell.edu/files/shared/documents/Recombinant%20Bovine%20Somatotropin_v3.pdf|website=Cornell University|publisher=Department of Animal Science}} Farmers who opt to use the synthetic hormone do so because they believe it increases milk production without other inputs. However, concerns of both product safety and livestock abuse have prompted discussions for new methods in assaying the levels of dairy cattle rBST. One proposed method involves quantifying the presence or absence of the rBST-binding antibody in serum. However, this method would require blood samples to be taken regularly and is thus considered by some critics{{Who|date=May 2017}} to be too invasive. The development of other alternative methods continue to undergo development. One such example, tested by W.W. Thatcher at the University of Florida,{{cite journal|title=Meta-analysis of the effects of sometribove zinc suspension on the production and health of lactating dairy cows|first1=Normand R.|last1=St-Pierre|first2=George A.|last2=Milliken|first3=Dale E.|last3=Bauman|first4=Robert J.|last4=Collier|first5=Joseph S.|last5=Hogan|first6=Jan K.|last6=Shearer|first7=K. Larry|last7=Smith|first8=William W.|last8=Thatcher|date=1 September 2014|publisher=|journal=J. Am. Vet. Med. Assoc.|volume=245|issue=5|pages=550‚Äì564|doi=10.2460/javma.245.5.550|pmid=25148097}} involves collecting milk samples from the cows and analyzing them directly for the presence of the rBST antibody. Dairy cattle do respond to the rBST angtigen and have shown positive results in immunosorbent trials on milk samples. Tests involving [[Pasteurization|pasteurized]] milk samples have even shown consistent results, with immunoglobulin rBST still detectable and distinguishable despite other antibodies remaining present. Research on the viability of this new technique, as well as many others,http://cn.agilent.com/cs/library/applications/5989-8481EN.pdf as a means of monitoring the levels of rBST in dairy cattle continues to be an issue of practicality, profitability, and humaneness towards livestock in the dairy industry.{{Cite journal|doi=10.1016/j.foodcont.2011.12.011|title=Monitoring milk for antibodies against recombinant bovine somatotropin using a microsphere immunoassay-based biomarker approach|journal=Food Control|volume=26|pages=68‚Äì72|year=2012|last1=Ludwig|first1=Susann K.J.|last2=Smits|first2=Nathalie G.E.|last3=Bremer|first3=Maria G.E.G.|last4=Nielen|first4=Michel W.F.}} ===United States=== In 1993, the product was approved for use in the U.S. by the FDA, and its use began in 1994. The product is now sold in all 50 states. The FDA stated that food products made from rBST-treated cows are safe for human consumption, and no statistically significant difference exists between milk derived from rBST-treated and untreated cows.{{cite web | url = http://www.fda.gov/AnimalVeterinary/SafetyHealth/ProductSafetyInformation/ucm130321.htm | title = Report on the Food and Drug Administration's Review of the Safety of Recombinant Bovine Somatotropin |accessdate=2 May 2009 | year = 1999 }} The FDA found BST to be biologically inactive when consumed by humans and found no biological distinction between rBST and BST. In 1990, an independent panel convened by the National Institute of Health supported the FDA opinion that milk and meat from cows supplemented with rBST is safe for human consumption.{{cite book |chapterurl=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK15180/ |chapter=Bovine Somatotropin |title=NIH State of the Science Statements |publisher=National Institutes of Health}} ====Labeling==== The FDA does not require special labels for products produced from cows given rBST, but has charged several dairies with "misbranding" its milk as having no hormones, because all milk contains hormones and cannot be produced in such a way that it would not contain any hormones.{{cite web |first1=Janet |last1=Raloff |date=November 2003 |title=Hormones in Your Milk |url=http://www.sciencenews.org/view/generic/id/4375/title/Food_for_Thought__Hormones_in_Your_Milk |work=[[Science News]] |access-date=6 August 2012}} Monsanto sued [[Oakhurst Dairy]] of Maine over its use of a label which pledged not to use artificial growth hormones.{{cite news | url = http://www.commondreams.org/headlines03/0708-10.htm | title = Oakhurst Sued by Monsanto Over Milk Advertising | last = Wickenheiser | first = M | work = [[Portland Press Herald]] | access-date = 29 January 2008 | date = 8 July 2003 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080201163140/http://www.commondreams.org/headlines03/0708-10.htm | archivedate = 1 February 2008 | df = dmy-all }} The dairy stated that its disagreement was not over the scientific evidence for the safety of rBST (Monsanto's complaint about the label), but, "We're in the business of marketing milk, not Monsanto's drugs." The suit was settled when the dairy agreed to add a qualifying statement to its label: "FDA states: No significant difference in milk from cows treated with artificial growth hormones." The FDA recommends this additional labeling, but does not require it.{{cite web |url=http://www.purefood.org/monsanto/mainegives122903.cfm |title=Maine Dairy Caves in to Pressure from Monsanto on rBGH-Free Labeling |publisher=Purefood.org |date=25 December 2003 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160106231643/http://www.purefood.org/monsanto/mainegives122903.cfm |archivedate=6 January 2016 |df=dmy-all }} The settlement itself caused much controversy, with anti-rBST advocates claiming that Oakhurst had capitulated in response to intimidation by a larger corporation and others claiming that Oakhurst's milk labels were in and of themselves using misleading scare tactics that deserved legal and legislative response. ==== Ohio ==== In 2008, Ohio's Department of Agriculture (ODA) banned the use of labeling in dairy products as rBST-free because it was deemed misleading to consumers. However, the International Dairy Foods Association and the Organic Trade Association claimed ODA's ban was a violation of the first amendment by not allowing consumers to decide whether they deem the milk was safe and filed suit against the bill. "The district court granted summary judgment in favor of Ohio, concluding that using "rBST" as a label was inherently misleading because it implies "a compositional difference between those products that are produced with rBST and those that are not."{{Cite journal|title = Recent Developments in Health Law|url = http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.1748-720X.2011.00554.x/abstract|journal = The Journal of Law, Medicine & Ethics|date = 2011-03-01|issn = 1748-720X|pages = 96‚Äì101|volume = 39|issue = 1|doi = 10.1111/j.1748-720X.2011.00554.x|language = en|first = Cordaro|last = Rodriguez|first2 = Elena|last2 = Papoulias}} ====Kansas==== In 2009, the [[Kansas Legislature]] passed a bill that would have required dairies that did not use rBST to print disclaimers on their labels that stated, "The Food and Drug Administration has determined there are no significant differences between milk from cows that receive injections of the artificial hormone and milk from those that do not." The bill was vetoed in the last days of the 2009 legislative session by then-Governor [[Kathleen Sebelius]]. The legislature removed the labeling language and passed the bill without the provision.{{cite web | url = http://www.ethicurean.com/2009/05/04/kansas-milk-labels/ | title = Kansas Senate leaves rBST milk labels on ag committee floor |accessdate=28 October 2011 | date = 23 April 2009 | format = PDF | publisher = [[Consumers Union]] }} ====Pennsylvania==== In 2007, [[Pennsylvania]] adopted a regulation that would have banned the practice of labeling milk as derived from cows not treated with rBST. Pennsylvania's Agriculture Secretary Dennis Wolff made the following statement in support of the measure:
Consumers are getting confused with the extra labels. They deserve a choice, and so do producers. But from the standpoint of safety, all milk is healthy milk. Our milk is a safe product. The Pennsylvania Department of Agriculture is not in a position to say use rBST or not. The key word is: choice. I used rBST from day one of its approval to the last day that I milked cows. It was an important management tool on my dairy farm. What we oppose is the negative advertising or the selling of fear. If producers are asked to give up a production efficiency, and if that efficiency nets them $3000 or $10,000 a year for their dairy farm  ... That's a lot of money.{{cite web |url=http://www.earthfarmfriendly.com/News/frustvenmilkmrkt-102606.html |title=Frustrations Vented Over Questionable Milk Marketing Practices ‚Äì October 26, 2006 |publisher=Earthfarmfriendly.com |date=26 October 2006 |accessdate=24 September 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110511210359/http://www.earthfarmfriendly.com/News/frustvenmilkmrkt-102606.html |archivedate=11 May 2011 |df=dmy-all }}
This prohibition was to go into effect 1 January 2008, but after the comment period, the guidelines were adjusted to only ban "rBST-free" claims and instead allow claims that farmers had pledged not to use rBST and accompany such claims with a disclaimer such as, "No significant difference has been shown between milk derived from rbST-treated and non-rbST-treated cows."{{cite news |url=http://www.post-gazette.com/pg/08018/850269-85.stm | title = State reverses on dairy labeling, allows hormone claims | date = 18 January 2008 |accessdate=29 January 2008 | last = Malloy | first = D | work = [[Pittsburgh Post-Gazette]] }} ==Response from milk producers and retailers== In response to concerns from consumers and advocacy groups about milk from cows treated with rBST, some dairies, retailers, and restaurants have published policies on use of rBST in production of milk products they sell, while others offer some products or product lines that are labelled "rBST-free" or the like. Other dairies and industry groups have worked to assure the public that milk from rBST-treated cows is safe. * The blue-and-white [[Dairy Farmers of Canada]] logo on a product indicates that the milk was sourced in Canada, from cows who were given no rBST.[https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/usmca-milk-hormones-1.4849423 cbc.ca: "Hormones, cows and the new trade deal: What you need to know"], 03 October 2018 * [[Costco]] has no overall rBST policy, but sells brands such as Kirkland with labels pledging that no rBST was used in milk production.{{cite web|url=http://www.costco.com/Browse/Product.aspx?prodid=10178011&whse=BD_115&topnav=bd&cat=7088&hierPath=6375*&lang=en-US |title=Offering thousands of items you won't find in your local Costco |publisher=Costco.com |date=22 June 2007 }} * [[Wal-Mart]] announced in March 2008 that its private-label Great Value milk will be "sourced exclusively from cows that have not been treated with artificial growth hormones like recombinant bovine somatotropin (rBST)"{{cite web|url=http://www.walmartstores.com/pressroom/news/8147.aspx |title=Walmart Corporate ‚Äì Wal-Mart Offers Private Label Milk Produced without Artificial Growth Hormone |publisher=Walmartstores.com |date=21 March 2008 }} * [[Kroger]] announced in April 2007, "it will complete the transition of milk it processes and sells in its stores to a certified rBST-free supply by February 2008."http://www.thekrogerco.com/corpnews/corpnewsinfo_pressreleases_08012007.htm * [[Dean Foods]] has no overall rBST policy, but has brands, such as Oak Farms, with labels pledging that no rBST was used in milk production.{{cite web|url=http://www.deanfoods.com/brands/oak-farms.aspx |title=Oak Farms Dairy |publisher=Dean Foods |date= }} * [[Winder Farms]], a home delivery dairy and grocer in Utah and Nevada, sells milk from rBST-free cows.{{cite web|url=https://homedelivery.winderfarms.com/OurProducts/NonloginProductDetail.aspx?id=00001142&source=B |title=Winder Farms |publisher=Homedelivery.winderfarms.com |date= }} * Guernsey Farms, a dairy farm and distributor located in Northville, Michigan, sells and distributes rBST-free dairy products in southeastern Michigan. Its milk has been labeled rBST-free for a number of years.{{cite web |url=http://www.guernseyfarmsdairy.com |title=Guernsey Farms Diary |year=2011}} * [[Safeway Inc.|Safeway]] in the northwestern United States stopped buying from dairy farmers who use rBST in January 2007. The two Safeway plants produce milk for all Safeway stores in Oregon, southwest Washington, and parts of northern California. Safeway's plant in [[San Leandro, California]], has been rBST-free since 2005. * [[Chipotle Mexican Grill]] announced in June 2012 that it will serve rBST-free [[sour cream]] at its restaurants.{{cite web|author=Associated Press |url=https://finance.yahoo.com/news/chipotle-using-products-pasture-raised-cows-150909650--finance.html |title=Chipotle using products from pasture-raised cows ‚Äì Yahoo! Finance |publisher=Finance.yahoo.com |date=19 June 2012 }} * [[Publix]] supermarket chain states on its website: "Publix milk is rBST-free. (No added artificial hormones.) However, the FDA has stated that no significant difference has been shown between milk derived from rbST-treated and non-rbST-treated cows."{{cite web|url=http://www.publix.com/about/qa/QAProducts.do#Q4 |title=Publix Q&A: Products |publisher=Publix.com |date=30 September 2008 }} * [[Braum's]], a dairy and ice cream retailer in the midwest with a private herd, says on its website that it does not administer rBST to its cows.{{cite web|url=http://www.braums.com/about-us/ |title=About Us | Braum's |publisher=Braums.com |date= }} * [[Starbucks]]'s website, as of August 2012, has no statement about use of milk from cows treated with rBST. For example, its animal welfare policy is silent on the issue.http://assets.starbucks.com/assets/a228b865c3aa45938b7508cb82a17cf1.pdf It announced in January 2008 that it would no longer sell milk from cows treated with rBST in its stores in the U.S.{{cite web|last=Adamy |first=Janet |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB120043442172092339 |title=Starbucks Less Organic - WSJ.com |publisher=Online.wsj.com |date=16 January 2008 }} The Organic Consumers Association, an advocacy group, claimed that Starbucks' change was due to their advocacy work.{{cite web|url=http://www.organicconsumers.org/articles/article_6826.cfm |title=Starbucks Agrees to Ban Monsanto's Bovine Growth Hormone from All Its Cafes by End of Year |publisher=Organicconsumers.org |date= }} * [[Oakhurst Dairy]] stopped using rBST in 2003 but still uses natural BST * [[Tillamook County Creamery Association]], a co-operative made up of 110 dairy farms, say its farmers pledge that their cows are not treated with hormones.{{cite web|url=http://www.tillamook.com/ourstory/our_values.html |title=Oregon Dairy Farmers |publisher=Tillamook |date= }} * [[Yoplait]], in 2009, General Mills announced it would stop using milk from cows treated with rBST, and stated, "While the safety of milk from cows treated with rBST is not at issue, our consumers were expressing a preference for milk from cows not treated with rBST, and we responded."Matt McKinney for the Minneapolis Star Tribune. 9 February 2009 [http://www.startribune.com/business/39344447.html General Mills to stop use of rBGH milk in Yoplait] * [[Upstate Niagara Cooperative]]'s entire milk supply is rBST-free.{{cite web|url=http://www.upstatefarms.com/products.cfm|title=Upstate Farms :: Products|first=FS Enablers, Amherst|last=NY|publisher=}} * [[Byrne Dairy]] requests that its farmers pledge not to use rBST; its entire fluid milk, cream, ice cream, and butter manufacture is sourced exclusively from such pledging farmers.{{cite web|url=http://www.byrnedairy.com/our-products/frequently-asked-questions/|title=Frequently Asked Questions|publisher=}} * [[Trader Joe's]] states, "Trader Joe's brand products contain NO ... dairy ingredients from rBST sources"{{cite web|url=http://traderjoes.com/contact-us/new-vendor-requirements|title=New Vendor Requirements - Trader Joe's|publisher=}} In reaction to these trends, in early 2008, a pro-rBST advocacy group called American Farmers for the Advancement and Conservation of Technology (AFACT),{{cite web|url=http://itisafact.org/ |title=AFACT: American Farmers for the Advancement and Conservation of Technology |publisher=Itisafact.org |date= }} made up of dairies and originally affiliated with Monsanto, formed and began lobbying to ban such labels. AFACT stated that "absence" labels can be misleading and imply that milk from cows treated with rBST is inferior.[https://www.nytimes.com/2008/03/09/business/09feed.html Fighting on a Battlefield the Size of a Milk Label] from ''[[The New York Times]]'' The organization was dissolved in 2011.{{cite web |url=http://itisafact.org/category/news/ |title=News | AFACT: American Farmers for the Advancement and Conservation of Technology |publisher=Itisafact.org |date=14 April 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130116120835/http://itisafact.org/category/news/ |archivedate=16 January 2013 |df=dmy-all }} The International Dairy Foods Association has compiled a list, last updated in 2009, of state regulations in the U.S. for referencing use of growth hormones on milk labels. ===Response from health organizations=== * The [[American Cancer Society]] "has no formal position regarding rBGH".{{cite web|title=The American Cancer Society|url=http://www.cancer.org/cancer/cancercauses/othercarcinogens/athome/recombinant-bovine-growth-hormone}} * The [[American Public Health Association]] (APHA) Policy #2000-11, "The Precautionary Principle and Children's Health, "encourages precautionary action to prevent potential harm to fetuses, infants, and children [from the continued manufacture and use of substances], even if some cause-and-effect relationships have not been established with scientific certainty."{{cite web|title=The American Public Health Association|url=http://www.apha.org/policies-and-advocacy/public-health-policy-statements/policy-database/2014/07/09/13/42/opposition-to-the-use-of-hormone-growth-promoters-in-beef-and-dairy-cattle-production}} * The [[American Nurses Association]] supports the development of national and state laws, regulations, and policies that specifically reduce the use of rBGH or rBST in milk and dairy production in the United States.{{cite web|title=American Nurses Association|url=http://www.nursingworld.org/MainMenuCategories/WorkplaceSafety/Healthy-Work-Environment/Environmental-Health/HealthyFoodinHealthCare.pdf}} ===Response from political organizations=== * [[Oregon Physicians for Social Responsibility]] recommends buying products from cows not injected with recombinant bovine growth hormone (rBGH or rBST).{{cite web|title=Oregon Physicians for Social Responsibility|url=http://action.psr.org/documents/dairyguide.htm}} * [[Health Care Without Harm]] opposes the use of recombinant bovine growth hormone due to its adverse impacts on animals and potential harm to humans.{{cite web|title=Health Care Without Harm|url=https://noharm.org/sites/default/files/lib/downloads/food/HCWH_Position_on_rBGH.pdf}} === Production and profitability === One study found a profit of $15.88 US per cow on average by using bST.{{cite book|last1=Tauer|first1=L.W.|editor1-last=Santaniello|editor1-first=Vittorio|editor2-last=Evenson|editor2-first=Robert E.|editor3-last=Zilberman|editor3-first=David|title=Market development for genetically modified foods|date=2001|publisher=CABI|location=Wallingford, Okon, UK|isbn=085199573X|pages=81‚Äì90|chapter=The impact of bovine somatotropin on farm profits}} ==See also== {{portal|Agriculture and Agronomy}} * [[Genetic engineering]] * [[Growth hormone treatment]] * [[Industrial agriculture]] * [[List of recombinant proteins]] * [[Recombinant DNA]] * [[Somatotropin family]] ==References== {{Reflist}} {{GH/IGF-1 axis signaling modulators}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Bovine Somatotropin}} [[Category:Agriculture in {{Infobox prepared food | name = Bundt Cake | image = Bundt Cake with Grapes 001.jpg | image_size = 267px | caption = A partially sliced Bundt cake | alternate_name = | country = [[United States]] | region = [[Minneapolis]] | creator = [[H. David Dalquist]] | course = [[Dessert]] | type = [[Cake]] | served = | main_ingredient = [[Flour]], [[sugar]], [[egg (food)|egg]]s | variations = | calories = | other = }} A '''Bundt cake''' {{IPAc-en|b| å|n|t}} is a [[cake]] that is baked in a '''Bundt pan''', shaping it into a distinctive ring shape. The shape is inspired by a traditional European cake known as {{lang|de|[[Gugelhupf]]}}, but Bundt cakes are not generally associated with any single recipe. The style of mold in [[North America]] was popularized in the 1950s and 1960s, after cookware manufacturer [[Nordic Ware]] trademarked the name "Bundt" and began producing Bundt pans from cast [[aluminum]]. Publicity from [[Pillsbury Company|Pillsbury]] saw the cakes gain widespread popularity.
==Etymology== [[File:Babka, M√∫nich, Alemania, 2013-04-01, DD 01.JPG|thumb|[[Babka (cake)]] in a Bundt shape]] The Bundt cake derives in part from a European [[brioche]]-like cake called {{lang|de|[[Gugelhupf]]}} which was particularly popular among [[Jews|Jewish]] communities in parts of [[Germany]], [[Austria]], and [[Poland]].<ref name=oxford>{{cite book |title=The Oxford Companion to Food |publisher = Oxford University Press |year = 2006 |isbn = 978-0-19-280681-9 |page = 441 |edition = 2nd |last = Davidson |first = Alan }}</ref> In the southwest of Germany {{lang|de|Gugelhupf}} is traditionally known as {{lang|de|Bundkuchen}} ({{IPA-de|Ààb äntkuÀêxnÃ©}}), a name formed by joining the two words {{lang|de|Bund}} and {{lang|de|Kuchen}} (cake).<ref name=wpost>{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/articles/A27813-2005Jan21.html |newspaper = [[The Washington Post]] |title = Who Brought the Bundt Cake? |date = 22 January 2005 |last = Pfrengle |first = Hermann |accessdate = 19 December 2012 }}</ref>
Opinions differ as to the significance of the word {{lang|de|Bund}}. One possibility is that it means "bunch" or "bundle", and refers to the way the dough is bundled around the tubed center of the pan.<ref name=wpost/> In Dutch, the cake is called "tulband," which is Dutch for 'turban.' The pronunciation of the second part of this word is very similar to that of 'bundt.' Another source suggests that it describes the banded appearance given to the cake by the fluted sides of the pan, similar to a tied [[sheaf (agriculture)|sheaf]] or bundle of wheat.<ref name=franklin>{{cite book |title = 300 Years of Kitchen Collectibles |last = Campbell Franklin |first = Linda |publisher = Krause Publications |pages = 187‚Äì8 |edition = 5th |ISBN = 978-0-87349-365-9 |year = 2003 }}</ref> Some authors have suggested that {{lang|de|Bund}} instead refers to a group of people, and that {{lang|de|Bundkuchen}} is so called because of its suitability for parties and gatherings.<ref name=wpostobit>{{cite news |title = Bundt Pan Creator H. David Dalquist, 86 |url = https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/articles/A51960-2005Jan5.html |date = 6 January 2005 |accessdate = 19 December 2012 |agency = [[Associated Press]] |newspaper = [[The Washington Post]] }}</ref><ref name=oklahoman>{{cite news |title = Bundt pan fans; Fluted cakes popular for six decades |newspaper = The Oklahoman |last = Dowell |first = Sharon |date = 17 May 2006 }}</ref>
Uses of the word ''bund'' outside of Europe to describe cakes can be found in [[American Jews|Jewish-American]] [[cookbook]]s from around the start of the 20th century.<ref name=babette>{{cite book |chapter=Plain Bund, or Napf Kuchen |title= Aunt Babette's Cook Book |url = http://digital.lib.msu.edu/projects/cookbooks/html/books/book_41.cfm |publisher = Block Pub and Print Co |place = Cincinnati |year = 1889 |pages = 326‚Äì327 |oclc = 3903063 }}</ref><ref name=meier>{{cite book |title=The Art of German Cooking and Baking |chapter = Bund-Kuchen |last = Meier |first = Lina |year = 1909 |publisher = Wetzel Bros Printing Co |place = Milwaukee |page = 337 |oclc = 13378934 }}</ref> The alternative spelling "bundte" also appears in a recipe as early as 1901.<ref name=kander>{{cite book |chapter = Bundte Kuchen |last = Kander |first = Lizzie Black |title = The Settlement Cook Book |year = 1901 |publisher = American Crayon Co |place = Sandusky, OH |accessdate = 19 December 2012 |url = http://www.wisconsinhistory.org/turningpoints/search.asp?id=910 }}</ref>
==Design== [[File:Napfkuchen-Form.jpg|thumb|left|Bundt-style pans in silicone and metal]] Bundt cakes do not conform to any single recipe; instead, their characterizing feature is their shape. A Bundt pan generally has fluted or grooved sides, but its most defining design element is the central tube or "chimney" which leaves a cylindrical hole through the center of the cake. The design means that more of the mixture touches the surface of the pan than in a simple round pan, helping to provide faster and more even heat distribution during cooking.<ref name=wpost/><ref name=fante>{{cite web |url = http://www.fantes.com/tube-pans.html |title = Tube Pans |accessdate = 20 December 2012 |publisher = Fante's }}</ref> The shape is similar to that of the earlier European {{lang|de|Gugelhupf}} or {{lang|de|Bundkuchen}}. A {{lang|de|Gugelhupf}} differs from contemporary Bundt-style cakes in that it follows a particular yeast-based recipe, with fruit and nuts, and is often deeper in shape and more decorative.<ref name=oxford/> Also similar in shape is the Eastern European ''[[Babka (cake)|Babka]]'', dating from early 18th century [[Poland]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.twojaeuropa.pl/1441/il-bab--ciastko-o-niezwyklym-smaku-i-historii|title=Il Bab√† - ciastko o niezwyk≈Çym smaku i historii|date=17 March 2010|last=Berny|first=Iwona|language=Polish|trans-title=Babka: a cake with a unique flavor and history}}</ref>
Today, there is no recipe for "Bundt cake". Anything can be baked in a Bundt-style pan, and is. Recipes range from ''Pine Nut and Chili'' cakes to ice cream and fruit concoctions. Bundt-style pan design has expanded beyond the original fluted ring to today's designs of skylines and cathedrals, all with the requisite hole in the center of the pan<ref name=BundtBook/> made by Nordic Ware and others. Since a [[Torus|toroidal]] cake is rather difficult to [[Icing (food)|frost]], Bundt cakes are typically either dusted with powdered sugar, drizzle-glazed, or served undecorated. Recipes specifically designed for Bundt pans often have a baked-in filling; Bundt [[pound cake]]s are also common.{{citation needed|date=November 2013}}
Since the name "Bundt" is a [[trademark]], similar pans are often sold as "fluted tube pans" or given other similar descriptive titles.<ref name=fante/> The trademark holder [[Nordic Ware]] only produces Bundt pans in aluminum, but similar fluted pans are available in other materials.<ref>[[:File:Napfkuchen-Form.jpg]]</ref>
==Rise to popularity== [[File:RainbowBundt.jpg|thumb|right|Rainbow Bundt cake, partially sliced]] The people credited with popularizing the Bundt cake are American businessman [[H. David Dalquist]] and his brother Mark S. Dalquist {{citation needed|date=November 2013}}, who co-founded [[cookware]] company [[Nordic Ware]] based in [[St. Louis Park, Minnesota]]. In the late 1940s,<ref name=BundtBook>{{cite book |title= Bundt Cake Bliss |last = Short |first = Susanna |publisher = Minnesota Historical Society Press |place = St. Paul |year = 2007 |chapter=And the Bundy was Born! |pages = 1‚Äì4 |ISBN = 978-0-87351-585-6 }}</ref> Rose Joshua and Fannie Schanfield, friends and members of the Minneapolis Jewish-American [[Hadassah|Hadassah Society]] approached Dalquist asking if he could produce a modern version of a traditional cast iron {{lang|de|[[Gugelhupf]]}} dish.<ref name=wpost/> Dalquist and company engineer Don Nygren designed a cast aluminum version which Nordic Ware then made a small production run of in 1950. In order to successfully trademark the pans, a "t" was added to the word "Bund".<ref name=oklahoman/> A number of the original Bundt pans now reside in the [[Smithsonian Institution|Smithsonian]] collection.<ref name=startribune>{{cite news |first = Matt |last = McKinney |url = http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=MN&p_theme=mn&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&s_dispstring=(Smithsonian%20gobbles%20up%20Bundt%20Pan%27)&p_field_advanced-0=&p_text_advanced-0=(%22Smithsonian%20gobbles%20up%20Bundt%20Pan%27%22)&xcal_numdocs=20&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&xcal_useweights=no |title = Smithsonian Gobbles up Bundt Pan |newspaper = Star Tribune |place = Minneapolis |date = 24 February 2007 |accessdate = 2007-03-01 }}</ref>
Initially, the Bundt pan sold so poorly that Nordic Ware considered discontinuing it.<ref name=startribune/> The product received a boost when it was mentioned in the ''New Good Housekeeping Cookbook'' in 1963,<ref name=anderson>{{cite book |title = American Century Cookbook: The Most Popular Recipes of the 20th Century |publisher = Clarkson Potter |place = New York |year = 1997 |page = 458 |ISBN = 978-0-517-70576-6 |last = Anderson |first = Jean }}</ref><ref name=nghcb>{{cite book |title = The New Good Housekeeping Cookbook |publisher = Harcourt, Brace & World |year = 1963 |place = New York |oclc = 378017 }}</ref> but did not gain real popularity until 1966, when a Bundt cake called the "Tunnel of Fudge", baked by Ella Helfrich, took second place at the annual [[Pillsbury Bake-Off]] and won its baker $5,000.<ref name=BundtBook/><ref name=anderson/> The resulting publicity resulted in more than 200,000 requests<ref name=BundtBook/> to Pillsbury for Bundt pans and soon led to the Bundt pan surpassing the tin [[Jell-O]] mold as the most-sold pan in the United States.{{citation needed|date=December 2012}} In the 1970s [[Pillsbury Company|Pillsbury]] licensed the name Bundt from Nordic Ware and for a while sold a range of Bundt cake mixes.<ref name=oklahoman/>
To date more than 60 million Bundt pans have been sold by Nordic Ware across North America.<ref name=nordic>{{cite web |url=http://www.nordicware.com/about |title=About Us |publisher = Nordic Ware |accessdate = 19 December 2012 }}</ref> November 15 has been named "National Bundt Day".<ref name="National Bundt Day">{{cite web |url=https://nationaldaycalendar.com/national-bundt-day-november-15/ |title=National Bundt Day |publisher = National Day Calendar }}</ref>
==See also== {{portal|Food}} * [[Angel food cake]], a North American sponge cake normally baked in a tube shaped pan * [[Wonder Pot]], a stovetop pot which uses a similar design * [[Gugelhupf]], Austrian, Swiss and German version with similar shape
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
== External links == * [http://www.mnopedia.org/thing/bundt-pan Bundt pan: MNopedia.] * [http://www.foodnetwork.com/topics/bundt-cake-recipes.html Bundt Cake Recipes]. [[Food Network]].
