{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2013}} {{Infobox organization |name = German Institute of Food Technologies(DIL) |image = Dil-logo-english.PNG |image_border = |size = 269px |alt = Abbreviated name of the German Institute of Food Technologies, DIL in forest-green colour with the microcellular graphic in two green colours and the official name of the DIL in black letters (below). |caption = <small>Official logo of the German Institute of Food Technologies</small> |map = |msize = |malt = |mcaption = |abbreviation = DIL |motto = Knowledge for superior foods |formation = 1983 <ref name="dil">DIL: [http://www.dil-ev.de/en/servicemenucontainer/servicemenu/about-us.html About DIL]. Accessed on 21 June 2010.</ref> |extinction = |type = Institution |status = Registered association |purpose = Research & Development |headquarters = [[Quakenbr√ºck]], Germany |location = [[Lower Saxony]], Germany |coords = |region_served = Germany, Worldwide |membership = |language = German, English |leader_title = Director |leader_name = Dr.-Ing.Volker Heinz <ref name="contact">DIL: [http://www.dil-ev.de/kontakt/ansprechpartner.html Contact partner]. Accessed on 21 June 2010.</ref> |main_organ = |parent_organization = |affiliations = |num_staff = approx. 150 <ref name="dil"/> |num_volunteers = |budget = |website = [http://www.dil-ev.de/en/home.html www.dil-ev.de] |remarks = }}
The '''German Institute of Food Technologies''' (ger. ''Deutsches Institut f√ºr Lebensmitteltechnik e.V.'' - DIL) is a [[Non-governmental organization|non-governmental]] and self-financing research institute supported by more than 120 members from fields of food production, [[mechanical engineering]], [[process engineering]] and [[metrology]]. The DIL was founded in 1983 and is situated in the [[Osnabr√ºck (district)|county of Osnabr√ºck]], one of the regions with the highest numbers of full-time employees and highest density of food industry enterprises in Germany.<ref name="eng">DIL Business [http://www.dil-ev.de/fileadmin/user_upload/pdf/dil-eng.pdf Statistics] Accessed on 22 June 2010.</ref>
The research focus of the DIL is to develop innovative methods for [[food production]], [[quality assurance]] and [[process optimization]]. Beneficiaries of new insights in food technology are small and medium-sized enterprises. Stated as main objective is the improvement of efficiency and increase of competitiveness of companies from the food industry.
According to own sources, the institute finances itself by 90% through external funds, out of which 55% are used to cooperate directly with members of the DIL.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20071128134744/http://www.dil-ev.de/staticsite/staticsite.php?menuid=4&topmenu=4&keepmenu=inactive DIL Introduction] Accessed on 22 June 2010</ref>
==History==
In May 1985, a new building was planned for the DIL in the [[Klaus von Klitzing|Professor-von-Klitzing]] Street, where the foundation stone was laid on September 1985 by [[Birgit Breuel]], who was Secretary of Commerce then. The [[Minister-President of Lower Saxony]] at that time, [[Ernst Albrecht (politician)|Ernst Albrecht]], inaugurated the new building at the turn of the year 1986/1987.
In 1988, the institute was renamed into its present name, "''German Institute of Food Technologies''", and its legal form was changed from membership cooperation to registered association.<ref name="PDF">CDL Lower Saxony [http://cdl.niedersachsen.de/blob/images/C28785004_L20.pdf Scientific Commission of Lower Saxony about the DIL]{{dead link|date=October 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} Accessed on 22 June 2010.</ref>
On 20 Mai 2009, the foundation stone for the expansion of the DIL building was laid by Friedrich-Otto Ripke, the Secretary of State for agriculture, nutrition, and consumer protection. The former Minister-President of Lower Saxony [[Christian Wulff]] and Hans-Heinrich Ehlen were thanked for their personal contribution to the grant which enables the German Institute of Food Technologies to cooperate and link itself with further research institutes in the county.<ref name="PDF"/><ref name="15euro">DIL Investment [http://www.dil-ev.de/en/servicemenucontainer/servicemenu/news-detail/article/15-millionen-euro-investition-im-artland/16.html - ‚Ç¨ 15 million investment for Artland municipality] Accessed on 22 June 2010.</ref>
As part of DIL's agenda for 2015, the current building had to be expanded. The state of Lower Saxony had agreed to support the [[Artland|Artland municipality]] with a subsidy of ‚Ç¨15 million to enable local agribusinesses and food production companies to develop their international competitiveness.<ref name="PDF"/>
==Business divisions==
===Product innovation=== New trends in markets and direct orders from companies serve as drive and guideline to develop appealing, healthy food products for all market segments: confectionery, baked goods, dairy and meat products, snacks and convenience products. The development process is also governed by a comprehensive analytical characterization of the structure of ingredients. Physical analysis in thermal, rheological and physiochemical tests enable possibilities to identify and characterize microstructures such as foams, emulsions and suspensions.<ref name="dil2">DIL Business [http://www.dil-ev.de/en/business-fields/product-development.html Business Fields Product development] Accessed on 23 June 2010.</ref>
===Process technology=== The focus of this business field is set to investigate in more efficient methods to process food production. Main goals include energy reduction, automation of technical processes and the use of new technologies to transform materials. The following areas are highlights of the process development: * [[Pulsed Electric Field Processing]] * [[Food extrusion|Extrusion]] * [[High pressure food preservation|High Pressure Processing]] * [[Ultrasound]]/Shockwave Technology * Application of [[supercritical fluid]]s <ref name="dil3">DIL Business [http://www.dil-ev.de/en/business-fields/process-development.html Business Fields Process development] Accessed on 23 June 2010.</ref>
===Food safety=== Products are tested upon their safety to avoid unforeseen incidents such as contamination of food. Raw material but also final products are being tested according to legal requirements and regulations in order to be safe for the consumer. Main areas of focus are [[quality management]], chemical- and microbiological analysis. Although the food producer alone carries the responsibility for the production of safe food and the implementation of the necessary measures, the DIL can support food producers through quality controls and seminars about hygiene management.<ref name="comp32">DIL Business Fields [http://www.dil-ev.de/en/business-fields/safety.html Business Fields Food safety] Accessed on 23 June 2010.</ref>
===Center of Food Physics=== The Center of Food Physics (ZLP) is the latest business division of the DIL ; it started operation in mid-2011. On behalf of its customers, the ZLP investigates the relationship between structure and function and transfers its findings on structure formation mechanisms into process technology. The scale-up of technical and industrial applications is conducted in cooperation with other DIL divisions in order to be able to process complex R&D tasks for its customers effectively and to a high level. While chemical analysis is concerned with the determination of the quality and quantity of substances and material systems, physical analysis applies expert knowledge, advanced measuring and examination methods and tailormade analysis concepts to characterize materials and material systems. Since structures are the key to understanding properties, this area is of particular importance. The work of the ZLP is methodology-oriented, which means that the central elements are the development and application of measuring techniques for physical characterization. The measuring methods will then be adapted to the respective material systems. The existing expertise and the available measuring and examination systems of the industry and other research institutes can thereby be offered as a service to minimize the gap between research and application.<ref name="service">DIL Annual Report [http://www.dil-ev.de/fileadmin/user_upload/pics/mitgliedschaft/Downloads/Jahresbericht_2011/DIL_Jahresbericht_Annual_report_2011.pdf]{{dead link|date=October 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} Accessed on 11 June 2012.</ref>
==Research==
===Bioeconomy=== Since 2012, the Bio-Economy division has been a new research focus at DIL. It serves as an interface between research platforms and business divisions. Cross-thematic and cross-sectoral research activities have been established to promote the structural change from an oil-based to a bio-based industry along with major opportunities for growth and employment. At the same time, international responsibility needs to be taken on the issues of the global food supply, the biomass-based supply of raw materials and energy, and climate and environmental protection. DIL is continually working to pave the way for bio-based food production. As part of these efforts, natural resources shall be used and new ways of using renewable raw materials are to be developed. This will be made possible through the development of new, bio-based production processes. This objective not only serves to preserve our living space, but also improves product quality and is good for our health. The division has its own research projects planned for 2013.
===Structure and functionality=== The quality of food is determined by their structure. Therefore, an optimization of food structures leads an improvement of long-term quality of food. Based on test on structure generation and the interdependency with the quality of food the DIL tries to increase the shelf-life of products.<ref name="compe">DIL Research [http://www.dil-ev.de/en/expertise/structure-and-functionality.html Structure & Functionality] Accessed on 23 June 2010.</ref>
===Proteintechnology=== When the Bio-Economy division was founded in 2012, it was accompanied by an extensive realignment and expansion of the research platforms. As a result, meat technology was removed from the Process Technology business division, the biotechnology focus was placed on enzyme and raw material research, and a new research platform was founded for feed technology. Together, these three areas comprise the Protein Technology research division. These newly created capacities are the key to an integrated approach to global problems in the area of Bio-Economy.
===Robotics=== New application areas for robotics are being researched, far away from the traditional image of robotics where robots are mostly used for packing processes. Safe and hygienic handling of unpacked and packed food products are main highlight in this field. Through cooperation with food producers, robotics engineers and manufacturers the DIL establishes new functions for robotics.<ref name="compe2">DIL Research [http://www.dil-ev.de/en/expertise/robotics.html Robotics] Accessed on 23 June 2010.</ref>
===Process analysis=== The optimization of existing (production) processes always increases the competitiveness of the entrepreneur. The implementation of advanced process analysis into existing systems allows the performance of the plants to be optimized further. On a daily basis sensor technology provides new and improved options for the collection of measuring data. Processing data can consequently be compiled with much higher precision and at shorter intervals. This allows the optimization of production parameters such as quality, pieces/minute, reject rate ‚Äì no matter whether it's anticipatory (e.g. by assessing the products introduced into the process) or downstream (e.g. control at the end of each process stage). This is where the value of the information becomes most visible. Many production plants are still not yet operating to their performance capabilities. There are many possibilities for process analysis to further improve the quality achieved so far.<ref name="service"/>
==Cooperations==
===Germany===
The ''Lower Saxonian competency center for the food industry'' (NieKE) is a network of cooperation between the German Institute of Food Technologies, ''The Institute of Spatial Analysis and Planning in Areas of Intensive Agriculture'' (ISPA) of the [[University of Vechta]], DIALOG - ''The Center for Transfer of Information and Technology'' at the [[University of Oldenburg]], ''the Competency Center Functional Food'' (KKF) and ''The Research and Technology Contact Center'' (unitransfer) at the [[University of Hanover]]. The aims of this cooperative network are knowledge sharing between the members and the support of small and medium-sized enterprises.<ref name="brochure">DIL Brochure [http://www.dil-ev.de/fileadmin/user_upload/pdf/dil-eng.pdf About DIL] Accessed on 24 June 2010.</ref><ref name="nieke">NieKE [http://www.ernaehrungswirtschaft.de/index.php?con_cat=1&con_lang=1&sid=tjobhkkso3ipbpnq141jgagml5 About NieKE] Accessed on 24 June 2010.</ref>
In May 2009 the University of Applied Sciences in Osnabr√ºck and the DIL signed an agreement for a long-term cooperation for future research and education. As result of this cooperation a statewide new academic course was established for the fall semester 2008; the Bachelor of Engineering ‚ÄúFood Production Engineering and Business‚Äù. The German Institute of Food Technologies functions as one of the main coordinating bodies.<ref name="fhosna">University of Applied Sciences Osnabr√ºck [http://www.fh-osnabrueck.de/722+M5ade6d7b14f.html New cooperation with DIL] Accessed on 24 June 2010</ref>
===International=== Along with the [[University of Groningen]], the Netherlands and the [[Netherlands Organisation for Applied Scientific Research]] (TNO), the DIL founded the ICCF (International Competence Center Food and Research Development) as research collaboration. This project was established to link closer cooperation and integration between the German and Dutch parts of the [[Ems Dollart Region]].<ref name="brochure"/> The German Institute of Food Technologies operates worldwide with customers from Japan, China, India, Australia and the USA. Among DIL's customers are [[Multinational corporation|global players]] such as [[Mars, Incorporated|Mars]], [[General Mills]] and [[Barilla Group|Barilla]].<ref name="brochure"/>
===HighTech Europe=== [[Image:Hightech Europe logo.png|thumb|right|200px|Official logo of HighTech Europe]] HighTech Europe is an initiative of European research organizations, industrial associations and enterprises with the goal of setting up a European Institute of Food Technology in order to share competences and knowledge of research available in Europe and to strengthen the resident industry for global competition. Long-term goal of the network of excellence is to achieve a long-lasting integration of the European R&D activities into high-tech food processing.
The network is coordinated by the DIL and sponsored by the 7th EU Framework Programme EU research sponsoring. Currently, the network counts 22 members, 21 being from Europe and one from Oceania. Project aims have been implemented by creating and applying various knowledge transfer tools. Network partners identified potential innovations from the biotechnology, nanotechnology, information- and communication technology and other areas to be used by food industry especially small and medium enterprises. Result is a unique database for the food processing sector, the Food Technology Innovation Portal (www.foodtech-portal.eu). Further results and network activities are available on the project website.<ref name="dilhichtech">HighTech Europe {{cite web |url=http://www.hightecheurope.eu/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-07-23 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=http://arquivo.pt/wayback/20160108072229/http%3A//www.hightecheurope.eu/ |archivedate=8 January 2016 |df=dmy-all }}. Accessed on 23 July 2013.</ref>
==References== <references/>
==External links== * [www.dil-ev.de/en.html Official Website - German Institute of Food Technologies (English, German)] * [http://www.elcrack.de Official Website - ELCRACK - Cell Disintegration and microbial decontamination (English)] * [http://www.hightecheurope.com Official Website - HighTech Europe (English)] * [http://www.al.fh-osnabrueck.de/28878.html Official Website - University of Applied Sciences Osnabr√ºck - Bachelor of Engineering Food Production Engineering and Business (English, German)]
{{DEFAULTSORT:German Institute Of Food Technologies}} [[Category:Agricultural research institutes in Germany]] [[Category:Food science institutes]] [[Category:Food technology organizations]]

{{expert needed|1=Engineering|date=June 2018}} [[File:Nyquist_grid.svg|thumb|Nyquist plot of the open-loop transfer function <math>G(s) = 1/(s+0.5)</math>in blue with M and N circles overlaid in the plot. The M circle with M = 0.45 is highlighted in red and intercepts the Nyquist plot at frequencies <math>\omega \approx \pm 1.64</math>.]] '''Hall circles''' (also known as M-circles and N-circles) are a graphical tool in [[control theory]] used to obtain values of a [[closed-loop transfer function]] from the [[Nyquist-plot|Nyquist plot]] (or the [[Nichols plot]]) of the associated open-loop transfer function. Hall circles have been introduced in control theory by Albert C. Hall in his thesis.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/857968901|title=The analysis and synthesis of linear servomechanisms|last=C.|first=Hall, Albert|date=1943|publisher=Technology Press, Massachusetts Institute of Technology|isbn=9780262080736|location=Cambridge|oclc=857968901}}</ref>
== Construction == Consider a closed-loop linear control system with open-loop transfer function given by [[transfer function]] <math>G(s)</math> and with a unit gain in the feedback loop. The closed-loop transfer function is given by <math display="inline"> T(s) = \frac{G(s)}{1+G(s)} </math>.
To check the stability of ''T''(''s''), it is possible to use the Nyquist stability criterion with the Nyquist plot of the open-loop transfer function ''G''(''s''). Note, however, that only the Nyquist plot of ''G''(''s'') does not give the actual values of ''T''(''s''). To get this information from the G(s)-plane, Hall proposed to construct the [[Locus (mathematics)|locus]] of points in the ''G''(''s'')-plane such that ''T''(''s'') has constant magnitude and the also the locus of points in the ''G''(''s'')-plane such that ''T''(''s'') has constant phase angle.
Given a positive real value ''M'' representing a fixed magnitude, and denoting G(s) by ''z'', the points satisfying <math display="block"> M = |T(s)| = \frac{|G(s)|}{|1+G(s)|} = \frac{|z|}{|1+z|} </math>are given by the points ''z'' in the ''G''(''s'')-plane such that the ratio of the distance between ''z'' and 0 and the distance between ''z'' and -1 is equal to ''M''. The points ''z'' satisfying this locus condition are [[circles of Apollonius]], and this locus is known in the context of control systems as ''M-circles''.
Given a positive real value ''N'' representing a phase angle, the points satisfying <math display="block"> N = \arg \left[\frac{G(s)}{1+G(s)}\right] = \arg[G(s)] - \arg[1+G(s)] = \arg[z] - \arg[1+z] </math>are given by the points z in the ''G''(''s'')-plane such that the angle between -1 and z and the angle between 0 and z is constant. In other words, the angle opposed to the line segment between -1 and 0 must be constant. This implies that the points z satisfying this locus condition are arcs of circles,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cut-the-knot.org/pythagoras/Munching/inscribed.shtml|title=Munching on Inscribed Angles|last=|first=|date=|website=cut-the-knot|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-05-25}}</ref> and this locus is known in the context of control systems as ''N-circles''.
== Usage == [[File:Nichols_chart.svg|thumb|Nichols plot of the transfer function 1/s(1+s)(1+2s) along with the modified M and N circles.]] To use the Hall circles, a plot of M and N circles is done over the Nyquist plot of the open-loop transfer function. The points of the intersection between these graphics give the corresponding value of the closed-loop transfer function.
Hall circles are also used with the [[Nichols plot]] and in this setting, are also known as Nichols chart. Rather than overlaying directly the Hall circles over the Nichols plot, the points of the circles are transferred to a new coordinate system where the ordinate is given by <math> 20 \log_{10}(|G(s)|) </math> and the abscissa is given by <math> \arg(G(s))</math>. The advantage of using Nichols chart is that adjusting the gain of the open loop transfer function directly reflects in up and down translation of the Nichols plot in the chart.
== See also ==

A '''high-field domain''' is a band of elevated field orthogonal to the equi-current lines and seen in photoconductive {{math|CdS}} and monochromatic light at the band edge as dark band was discovered by B√∂er,<ref name="Boer1959">Karl W. B√∂er, Z. Physik 155, 184 (1959)</ref> using the [[Franz-Keldysh effect]]. Such domains must appear<ref name="Boer1959" /> whenever the conductivity decreases stronger than linearly. This can be caused by the field dependence of the carrier density, as observed in copper-doped {{math|CdS}} caused by Frenkel Poole excitation of holes, causing faster electron recombination, known as field quenching.<ref name="BoerDussel1967">Karl W. B√∂er and G. A. Dussel Phys. Rev. 154, 291 (1967)</ref> These high-field domains, now referred to as [[high-field domain#B√∂er domains|B√∂er domains]], or by field dependence of the mobility,<ref>Karl W. B√∂er Monatsber. d. Deutsch Akadem. d. Wissensch. 1, 325 (1959)</ref> caused by excitation of electrons into higher conduction bands with lower mobility as observed in {{math|GaAs}}, called the [[Gunn effect]].<ref>J.B.Gunn Solid State Commun. 1, 88 (1963)</ref><ref>H. Kroemer, Proceedings IEEE 52, 1230 (1961)</ref> The high-field domains can be identified by periodical field oscillations between high (the domain) and low values, as shown in Fig. 1.<ref name="Canta1993">Cantapediera, I.R., et al. Phys. Rev. B48, 12278 (1993)</ref> [[File:Pco-gunn-diode-fig-time.jpg|thumb|left|Fig. 1 Periodic current oscillation in a Gunn diode.<ref name="Canta1993" />]]
Many other crystals show such domains by typical current oscillations. The high-field domains in copper doped {{math|CdS}} can be easily observed by the [[Franz-Keldysh effect]] as stationary, adjacent to the cathode<ref name="BoerVoss1968">Karl W. B√∂er and P. Voss, Phys. Rev. 171, 899 (1968)</ref><ref name="BoerVoss1968-2">Karl W. B√∂er and P. Voss, phys. status solidi 28, 355 (1968)</ref> or moving.<ref name="Schoell1978">E. Schoell,Non-equilibrium Phase Transitions in Semiconductors, Springer, Berlin (1978)</ref><ref name="Shaw1987">M.P. Shaw, V.V. Mitin, and H.L. Grubin The Physics of Instabilities in Solid State Electerronic Devices Plenum Press New York (1987)</ref> These are analyzed as another example below.
Theory: Stationary high-field domains can be analyzed from the transport- and Poisson equations:
<math>\frac{dn}{dx}=\frac{e}{kT}\left (\frac{j}{e\mu}-nF\right )</math> {{pad|2em}} and {{pad|2em}} <math>\frac{dF}{dx}=\frac{e}{\epsilon\epsilon_0}\left (n-n_a\right )</math>
The projection of any solution curves into an arbitrary {{math|<var>nF</var>}} plane can be filled with direction arrows at any point of this plane. Two auxiliary curves for which {{math|<var>dn/dx</var> {{=}} 0}}, called {{math|<var>n</var><sub>2</sub>(<var>F</var>)}} and {{math|<var>dF/dx</var> {{=}} 0}} called {{math|<var>n</var><sub>1</sub>(<var>F</var>)}} divide this plane into four quadrants with the same type of directions. This is shown in Fig. 2(left) in a double logarithmic representation.<ref name="BoerVoss1968" /> Any solution of an {{math|<var>n</var>}}-type semiconductor with blocking cathode must start at the boundary density {{math|<var>n</var><sub><var>c</var></sub>}} that is below the density in the bulk, and approaches the singular point at which {{math|<var>dn/dx</var> {{=}} <var>dF/dx</var> {{=}} 0}}, that is in the bulk where both {{math|<var>n</var>(<var>x</var>)}} and {{math|<var>F</var>(<var>x</var>)}} are constant. The solution curve represents a [[schottky contact|Schottky-blocking contact]] as shown in Fig. 2(B), curve (a).<ref name="BoerVoss1968-2" /> {{multiple image | align = center | footer = Fig. 2 (left) Field of direction (B) Schottky solution, curve (a). With increased bias {{math|<var>n</var><sub>2</sub>(<var>F</var>)}} shifts steadily up and to the right, and may start to cross the declining branch of {{math|<var>n</var><sub>1</sub>(<var>F</var>)}}, caused by field-quenching; this creates a second singular point (II). When this point coincides with the boundary density {{math|<var>n</var><sub>c</sub>}}, a high-field domain solution (b) develops.<ref name="BoerVoss1968-2" /> | image1 = (left) Field of direction (B) Schottky type solution.jpg | alt1 = (left) | width1 = {{#expr: (250 * 288 / 220) round 0}}
| image2 = (B) Schottky type solution.jpg | alt2 = (B) | width2 = {{#expr: (250 * 246 / 208) round 0}} }}
When {{math|<var>n</var>(<var>x</var>)}} decreases at higher fields due to field-quenching cause by [[Poole-Frenkel effect|Poole-Frenkel]] excitation of holes from Coulomb attractive hole traps, that consequently enhances electron recombination through recombination centers, and thereby deforms the {{math|<var>n</var><sub>1</sub>(<var>x</var>)}} curve at higher fields as shown in Fig. 2(B). When the bias is increased the current curve {{math|<var>n</var><sub>2</sub>(<var>x</var>)}} is shifted upwards and to the right, and when it crosses {{math|<var>n</var><sub>1</sub>(<var>x</var>)}} again, it produces a second singular point II. With further increased bias this singular point II reaches the value of the boundary density {{math|<var>n</var><sub>c</sub>}}, and the solution curve changes from a monotonic increasing Schottky-solution, to a high-field domain, curve (b): that remains constant near the cathode, and then changes within a few [[Debye length]]s to approach the constant value in the bulk, near the singular point I. The width of the domain increases with bias (Fig. 3a), while the current remains constant (Fig. 3c).<ref name="BoerVoss1968-2" /> The domain is visible as dark part in the transmission picture through the {{math|CdS}} platelett, extending from the cathode as shown in Fig. 3a. The field in the domain can be obtained from the slope of the domain that increases with bias (Fig. 3b).<ref name="BoerVoss1968-2" />
[[File:(a) High-Field Domain dark region (b) Domain width vs. bias (c) current voltage characteristic.jpg|frame|center|Fig. 3 (a) High-Field Domain [dark region] shown as transmission near the band edge through the {{math|CdS}} platelett (b) Domain width vs. bias (c) current voltage characteristic<ref name="BoerVoss1968-2" /> showing the constant branch as soon as the domain appears.]]
When, with further increased bias the domain fills the entire sample,then it flips to an anode adjacent high-field domain (Fig. 4b). The field at the cathode is now much higher than for the cathode adjacent domain (Fig. 4b and c), while the current still remains essentially constant (Fig. 4c).<ref name="BoerVoss1968" />
{{multiple image | align = center | footer = Fig. 4 (a) Transmission picture of a {{math|CdS}} crystal with [[Franz-Keldysh effect]] darkening, that shows from 0 to -1,700 V bias the cathode adjacent domain, and from 2,200 to -3,200V the anode adjacent domain; the boundary of the domain is identified by a couple of arrows: (c) the domain width as function of bias (A) for cathode- (B) for anode-adjacent domain. (a) current-voltage characteristic (b) showing current saturation through the transition point at 2 {{math|kV}} bias.<ref name="BoerVoss1968" />
| image1 = (c) domain width as function of bias (A) for cathode- (B) for anode-adjacent domain. (d) current-voltage characteristic showing saturation through the transition point at 2 kV bias.jpg | alt1 = (c) domain width as function of bias (A) for cathode- (B) for anode-adjacent domain. (d) current-voltage characteristic showing saturation through the transition point at 2 kV bias | width1 = {{#expr: (175 * 251 / 123) round 0}}
| image2 = (b) Transmission picture of a CdS crystal with Franz-Keldysh effect darkening, 0-1,700 V bias cathode adjacent, 2,200 - 3,200V anode adjacent domain.jpg | alt2 = (b) Transmission picture of a CdS crystal with [[Franz-Keldysh effect]] darkening, 0-1,700 V bias cathode adjacent, 2,200 - 3,200V anode adjacent domain | caption2 = <center>'''(c)'''</center> | width2 = {{#expr: (175 * 182 / 142) round 0}} }}
'''High-field domains to determine the [[work function]] of blocking contacts'''
Since the high field domain starts at the electron density given by the work-function at the cathode and pulls the [[Schottky barrier]] open to a constant field in the domain, this [[work function]] can be determined precisely, and it can be used as a tool to determine the changes of the [[work function]], as it varies depending on external parameters. As an example, it can be shown that it depends on the optical excitation in a photoconductor (See Fig. 5).<ref name="Stirn1973">R. J. Stirn, K. W. B√∂er, and G. A. Dussel, Phys. Rev. B 7.4, 1443 (1973)</ref> [[File:4(C) Work function as function of the light intensity for different cathode metals.jpg|frame|left|Fig. 5 (a) [[Work function]] as function of the light intensity for different cathode metals.<ref name="Stirn1973" />]]
'''High-field domains as tools to measure the electron density in the field quenched branch and of the electron mobility as a function of the temperature''' [[File:5 Shadow band within a photoconductor changes conductivity and field within the Band.jpg|frame|right|Fig. 6 Shadow band within a photoconductor changes conductivity and field within the Band and thereby the boundary density at the right side of the band, i.e., it acts as a pseudo-cathode<ref name="BoerVoss1968-2" /> with the high-field domain starting at the anode-side of the pseudo-cathode.]]
The high-field domain is determined by the boundary density at the cathode and the field within the domain. A shadow band in front of the cathode acts as a pseudo-cathode, as it reduces the electron density within the shadow (Fig. 6).<ref name="BoerVoss1968-2" /> This can be used as an experimental tool to change the boundary density as a function of the light intensity within the shadow.
This permits to measure directly the electron density in the field-quenched range, using different pseudo-electron densities, causing a shift of the singular point, and measuring the domain field.<ref name="BoerVoss1968-2" />
The electron [[Hall mobility#Hall mobility|Hall mobility]] can be measured by placing the {{math|CdS}} platelett in a magnet and applying a bias sufficient to create a high-field domain. When the domain is extended to include the Hall electrodes one can determine the [[Hall mobility#Hall mobility|Hall mobility]] within the domain. Different fields in the high-field domain are achieved by using different samples or different cathode metals.<ref name="BoerBogus1968">K. W. B√∂er and K. Bogus, Phys. Rev. 186, 793 (1968)</ref>
'''Stationary domains to explain efficiency improvement of {{math|CdTe}} solar cells with a thin {{math|CdS}} cover layer'''
The application of a 200√Ö thick copper doped layer of {{math|CdS}} on top of a typically 2 Œºm thick {{math|CdTe}} solar cell, increases the [[open circuit voltage]] substantially, so that it can reach the theoretical limit of the band gap of the {{math|CdTe}}-emitter when extrapolated to 0 {{math|K}}. This improvement can be explained by limiting the field in the {{math|CdS}} side of the junction when it reaches the critical value for a high-field domain to appear and thereby limits the maximum junction field to the domain field of typical 50 {{math|kV/cm}}.<ref name="BoerHansch1959">K. W. B√∂er, H. J. H√§nsch and U K√ºmmel, Z. f√ºr Physik 155, 170 (1959)</ref> This field is below a field in which electron leaking from the {{math|CdS}} into {{math|CdTe}} occurs, resulting in an increase of the open circuit voltage and thereby an increase of the [[solar cell efficiency|solar cell conversion efficiency]].<ref name="Boer2010">Karl W.B√∂er, J. Appl.Phys. 107 (2010), 023701</ref>
'''Moving high-field domains in copper-doped {{math|CdS}} with a small circular cathode'''
The domains started from the cathode, separates and, with increasing bias increases its radius. When the anode is reached the ring disappeared and a new domain grows from the cathode. The process repeated itself with a period of 10 sec (Fig. 7).<ref name="Boer1959" /><ref name="Boer2011">K.W. B√∂er, Visualization of field and current inhomogeneities, Springer Verlag (2011)</ref> [[File:8(a)(b)(c) Ring of a high-field domain, made visible using the Franz-Keldysh effect.jpg|frame|left|Fig. 7: Ring of a high-field domain, made visible using the [[Franz-Keldysh effect]], circling the cathode and expanding in time 3 sec between (a), (b), and (c).<ref name="Boer2011" />]]
Such undeformed moving domains in crystals with slit electrodes are bands parallel to the electrodes, and seen by the oscillating field, when plotted in a {{math|x,F,t}} diagram give the optical impression of bifurcation (Fig. 8).<ref name="Canta1993" />
[[File:11 - Bifurcation of a high-field domain in p-type Ge; three dimensional rendering with the electric field shown vs. position and time.png|right|thumb|Fig. 8 Calculated high-field domains in Ge with the field as function of the time in a three-dimensional rendering.<ref name="Canta1993" />]]
Such moving high-field domains are measured in p-Ge with (a) local voltage (b) field- and (c) carrier density oscillation (Fig. 9).<ref name="Kahn1991">Kahn, A. M. et al., Phys. Rev. B 43, 9742 (1991)</ref> [[File:Measured High-Field Domain in Ge (a) (b) (c).jpg|right|thumb|Fig. 9 Measured High-Field Domain in Ge (a) local voltage (b) local field (c) Electron Density, all as function of the distance between the two electrodes. In all figures the time is the family parameter and the scale each graph of the figure is identified by a bar at the lower left.<ref name="Kahn1991" />]]
Undeformed moving high-field domains and domains with deformation (Chaos) are observed in many other crystals,<ref name="Schoell2001">Eckehard Schoell, Non-linear SpatioTemporal Dynamics and Chaos in Semiconductors Cambridge University Press, (2001)</ref> and also in nanocrystals<ref>K.N. Akkeseev et al. Phys. Rev. B 52,7849 (1995)</ref> or superlatices.<ref>L.L. Bonilla et al. Solid State E 140,161 (1996).</ref> However, because of the small size they can only be analyzed by the changing shape of the current-voltage characteristics.
{{Anchor|B√∂er domains}}'''B√∂er domains'''
The high-field domains were renamed B√∂er domains at the 50th anniversary of their discovery.<ref>Klaus Thiessen, Phys. stat. sol. (2011) {{DOI|10.1002/pssb.20146605}}</ref>
{{Anchor|The Benefits of the High-Field Domains}}'''The Benefits of the High-Field Domains'''
Copper-doped photoconductive CdS shows high-field domains when at sufficient bias and with blocking contacts these domains remain attached to the contacts. The field within the domain is constant and the current is by drift only. With increased bias the domain width increases. When it reaches both electrodes the entire crystal becomes space-charge free (this is one more example at which an interaction vanishes: for the interaction of electrons with phonons, superconductivity results; from the interaction of photons with phonons, lasers can be produced). This gives the opportunity to measure the spectral distribution of defect levels free of interaction of the broadening electric field surrounding the defects. A first example is shown by the extremely sharp quenching spectrum of a CdS crystal that has been inverted to become p-type with a high-field-domain (Fig. 10)
[[File:High field domain signal.png|thumb|Fig. 10 Electron-photo quenching signal (shown in red) in a p-type ultra-pure CdS crystal. The insert show the spectral distribution of the monochromator used that has no anomalies in the range of the signal.<ref name="Boer:2015">B√∂er, K. W. (2015), The importance of gold-electrode-adjacent stationary high-field B√∂er domains for the photoconductivity of CdS. Ann. Phys., 527: 378‚Äì395. {{DOI|10.1002/andp.201500115}}</ref>]]
Another benefit of the high-field domain is the direct connection of any p-type emitter through a copper-doped thin CdS layer directly to an electron-blocking electrode through which the holes are extracted, and the open circuit voltage is increased to approach the theoretical limit of the band gap or the emitter at 0K. Because in the CdS the hole current is now carried by drift only, we can finally draw the band model of a typical solar cell. e.g. the CdS/CdTe cell as given in Fig. 11. For the first time we can replace the estimate of the band connection of abrupt hetero-junctions from the difference of electron affinities by calculating it from the continuity of the majority carrier current, with the only small discontinuity left by the difference of the effective masses of the carriers at the different carrier bands.
[[File:Cdte.png|thumb|Fig. 11 Band model of the CdS/CdTe solar cell in operating condition at AM1.<ref name="Boer:2015a">B√∂er, K. W., High-field domains in CdS adjacent to a junction of p-type solar cells. J. Appl. Phys. 119, 085703 (2016); https://dx.doi.org/10.1063/1.4942358</ref>]]

{{update|date=June 2017}} {{Infobox company | name = IPtronics A/S | logo = IPtronics logo.JPG | logo_size = 150px | type = | foundation = Copenhagen, Denmark ({{Start date|2003|9}}) | location = Copenhagen, Denmark | industry = [[Semiconductors]] | products = Low-Power Single- & Multi-Channel Broadband Transimpedance Amplifiers (TIA) and VCSEL Drivers for Optical Data Communication Applications | owner = | num_employees = | parent =[[Mellanox Technologies]] | subsid = IPtronics Inc.,
[[Menlo Park, California]]. | homepage = {{URL |www.iptronics.com}} | footnotes = }} '''IPtronics''' was a [[fabless semiconductor company]] headquartered in [[Copenhagen]], [[Denmark]]. Its products include [[integrated circuits]] for parallel [[optical interconnect]] applications intended for the computer, storage and communication industries.{{cite news|url=http://investing.businessweek.com/research/stocks/private/snapshot.asp?privcapId=22274761|title=IPtronics: Private Company Information|publisher=[[BusinessWeek]]}}{{cite news|url=http://fibresystems.org/cws/product/P000008928|title=IPtronics Enables 40GE, 100GE and Beyond‚Ä¶|publisher=FiberSystems.org |date=December 16, 2008|accessdate=March 20, 2009}} IPtronics' design center is certified by [[STMicroelectronics]], which is also their [[semiconductor foundry]] partner.{{cite news|url=http://iptronics.com/36958/Partners/|title=IPtronics: About Us: Partners| publisher=IPtronics |accessdate=March 20, 2009}} In June 2013, IPtronics was acquired by [[Mellanox Technologies]].{{cite news|url=http://www.nasdaq.com/article/mellanox-technologies-ltd-announces-definitive-agreement-to-acquire-iptronics-as-20130604-00196 | title= Mellanox Technologies Ltd. Announces Definitive Agreement to Acquire IPtronics A/S |work= Press release |accessdate=June 4, 2013}}{{cite news|url=http://www.navidob.com/2013/07/05/iptronics-acquired-by-mellanox-technologies/ | title= IPtronics acquired by Mellanox Technologies | publisher=navidob.com |accessdate=August 22, 2013}} ==History== IPtronics was founded in 2003 and built up by former directors, managers and engineers from Giga A/S, which was acquired by [[Intel Corporation]] in 2000 for $1.25 billion USD.{{cite web|url=http://www.eetimes.eu/206800294|title=News|publisher=www.eetimes.eu}}{{cite news|url=http://news.cnet.com/Intel-to-buy-Giga-for-1.25-billion/2100-12_3-265102.html|title=Intel to buy Giga for $1.25 billion |publisher=CNET |date=March 15, 2000|accessdate=March 20, 2009}} On June 4, 2013, it was announced that IPtronics was acquired by [[Mellanox Technologies]] at a total cash purchase price of approximately $47.5 million, subject to certain adjustments. ===Founders and staff=== Three former Giga employees, Niels Finseth, Steen Bak Christensen, and Eivind Johansen, co-founded IPtronics. Giga A/S specialized in products for [[telecommunication]] and [[data communication]] applications, as for example [[OC-48]] and [[OC-192]]. Finseth was previously an engineering manager, responsible for all 10 [[Gbit/s]] IC product development. Mr. Christensen was also previously an engineering manager, responsible for all 2.5 Gbit/s development. Johansen was a co-founder of Giga (1987) as well, serving as the technical director until the acquisition by Intel, followed by a CTO position at Intel's Optical Component Division (OCD) and being appointed Intel Fellow in 2001, a corporate VP position for his technical leadership in [[optical communication]]. In May 2004, Henning Lysdal was recruited as COO, previously high-speed [[PHY]] development manager at Intel OCD.{{cite news|url=http://www.opticalkeyhole.com/eventtext.asp?ID=75465&pd=2/20/2008&bhcp=1|title=IPtronics, supplier of silicon for parallel optical interconnects, raises $10.25m in series B funding round|publisher=Optical Key Hole|date=February 19, 2008|accessdate=July 21, 2010}} Lysdal later became VP of engineering after hiring a dedicated director of operations. Two former colleagues from Giga/Intel, who were at that time CEOs in their respective Danish electronic companies, were recruited to IPtronics. Steen Gundersen came from a position as the CEO of Alight Technologies and Jesper Wolf Bek came from a position as the CEO of Kaleido Technology. In the beginning, the founders worked together in the garage of Steen Bak Christensen in Roskilde. As the first employee was hired in February 2005, IPtronics moved into new premises outside Roskilde.{{cite web |title=IPtronics, supplier of silicon for parallel optical interconnects, raises $10.25m in series B funding round|url=http://www.opticalkeyhole.com/eventtext.asp?ID=75465&pd=2/20/2008&bhcp=1|publisher=Optical Keyhole|date=February 20, 2008|accessdate=November 22, 2010}} Giga had customer support.{{cite news|url=http://www.business.dk/finans/giga-venner-satser-paa-lave-ny-giga|title=Giga-venner satser p√• at lave ny Giga|publisher=Business.dk|date=February 19, 2008|accessdate=July 22, 2010}} In 2006, Intel closed its Danish office, which resulted in even more new electronics start-ups in [[Copenhagen metropolitan area]] as well as many employees joining already existing companies such as IPtronics.{{cite web |url=http://www.ue.dk/nyhedsarkiv/5921.aspx |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-05-13 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110719132508/http://www.ue.dk/nyhedsarkiv/5921.aspx |archivedate=2011-07-19 |df= }} However, several new additions to the staff from 2008 and beyond have a different background than from Giga or Intel, such as Navid Ostadian-Binai. During 2006, the company appointed J√∏rgen Bardenfleth as chairman of the board of directors. Bardenfleth is the country general manager of [[Microsoft]] Denmark.{{cite news|url=http://www.globalisering.dk/multimedia/Jorgen_Bardenfleth.pdf|title=J√∏rgen Bardenfleth - Adm. Direkt√∏r, Microsoft Denmark|publisher=Globalisering.dk|accessdate=Nov 25, 2010}}{{cite news|url=http://www.opticalkeyhole.com/eventtext.asp?ID=62503&pd=10/13/2006&bhcp=1|title=IPtronics, developing optical interconnect products, closes $2m in second round funding|publisher=Optical KeyHole|date=October 13, 2006|accessdate=Nov 25, 2010}} In November 2011, IPtronics announced Martin Rofheart as chairman.{{cite news|url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/iptronics-appoints-dr-martin-rofheart-chairman-of-the-board-134637198.html|title=High Speed Analog, Optical and Wireless Semiconductor Executive Brings Global Market Expansion Expertise to IPtronics Board of Directors|publisher=[[PR Newswire]]|accessdate=Nov 29, 2011}}{{cite news|url=http://www.iptronics.com/38284/IPtronics%20Appoints%20Dr.%20Martin%20Rofheart%20Chairman%20of%20the%20Board/|title=IPtronics Appoints Dr. Martin Rofheart Chairman of the Board| publisher=IPtronics |accessdate=November 29, 2011}} ===Early products=== The company's first customer was [[CERN]], the European Organization for Nuclear Research. The IPtronics chips were produced with [[TriQuint Semiconductor]]'s [[GaAs]] foundry process technology. These devices are being used as front-end electronics for Resistive Plate Chambers (RPC), a gaseous [[particle detector]] capable of sub-nanosecond time resolution on very large areas.{{cite news| url=https://www.reuters.com/article/pressRelease/idUS125397+07-Oct-2008+BW20081007 | work=Reuters | title=TriQuint Powered Integrated Circuits Used in "Big Bang" Experiment at CERN Facility | date=October 7, 2008}} In October 2005, IPtronics started developing optical interconnects in a collaboration with NEC Corporation.{{cite news| url=http://www.opticalkeyhole.com/eventtext.asp?ID=62503&pd=10/13/2006&bhcp=1|publisher=Optical KeyHole | title=IPtronics, developing optical interconnect products, closes $2m in second round funding| date=October 13, 2006}}{{cite news| url=http://www.iptronics.com/37345/NEC+and+IPtronics+cooperate+on+tiny+optical+module|publisher=IPtronics | title=IPtronics cooperate with NEC on tiny optical module - IPtronics enables low power modules| date=October 3, 2005}} ===Expansion=== During the summer of 2008, IPtronics opened its North American office in [[Silicon Valley]].[https://web.archive.org/web/20091015030656/http://www.iptronics.com/37456/IPtronics%20Incorporated/ ] In April 2010, IPtronics joined the [[InfiniBand Trade Association]],{{cite web |title=InfiniBand Trade Association: Member roster|url=http://www.infinibandta.org/content/pages.php?pg=about_us_roster|accessdate=May 4, 2010}}{{cite news|url=http://www.prweb.com/releases/2010/04/prweb3929424.htm|title=InfiniBand Trade Association (IBTA) Announces Release of New Publication: Introduction to InfiniBand for End Users|publisher=[[PRWeb]]|date=April 27, 2010|accessdate=May 4, 2010}} which promoted [[InfiniBand]] technology. IPtronics announced it would offer low power and high volume products.{{cite news|url=http://www.iptronics.com/37770/IPtronics%20Offers%20low%20cost%20Silicon%20for%20Parallel%20Optics/|title=IPtronics Offers low cost Silicon for Parallel Optics - IPtronics adds solutions for the growing Low Cost and HDMI market in Asia|date=June 2010|publisher=IPtronics|accessdate=November 22, 2010}} IPtronics later also joined the associations, [[Optical Internetworking Forum]] and [[PCI-SIG|Peripheral Component Interconnect Special Interest Group]].{{cite news|url=http://www.oiforum.com/|title=Optical Internetworking Forum|publisher=Optical Internetworking Forum|accessdate=July 24, 2012}}{{cite news|url=http://www.pcisig.com/membership/about_us/membership_roster/|title=PCI-SIG Membership Roster|publisher=PCI-SIG|accessdate=July 24, 2012}} [[File:IPtronics - Parallel Optical Interconnects - STMicroelectronics wafers.jpg|thumb|upright |alt=Semiconductor wafers, showing IPtronics designed ICs for parallel optical interconnects using a STMicroelectronics fabrication process|Semiconductor wafers, showing IPtronics designed ICs for parallel optical interconnects using a STMicroelectronics fabrication process]] ==Technology== This technology enables parallel optical interconnect systems that computer manufactures have begun to adopt in order to overcome the physical constraints from using copper-based connections over high speed interfaces and [[backplanes]].[http://fibresystems.org/cws/article/newsfeed/32972] {{dead link|date=November 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}http://www.commsdesign.com/showArticle.jhtml?articleID=206800904 [[Parallel optical interface|Parallel optics]] is introduced to be able to simultaneously transmit and receive data at high [[Bandwidth (computing)|bandwidths]] over multiple fibers, initially implemented in supercomputers and servers followed by an upcoming introduction into consumer electronics.{{cite news|url=http://www.iptronics.com/36209/Optical%20interconnects.html|title=Parallel Optical Interconnects|last=Bek|first=Jesper|date=2008-06-09|publisher=IPtronics|accessdate=2010-04-09|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110305124306/http://www.iptronics.com/36209/Optical%20interconnects.html|archivedate=2011-03-05|df=}} In June 2011, IPtronics announced it had reached a shipment milestone, passing 1 million ICs, and the company states the majority is shipped to Asia.{{cite news|url=http://www.iptronics.com/38122/IPtronics%20Reaches%20Shipment%20Milestone%20/|title=IPtronics Reaches Shipment Milestone - The company also states to have qualified solder bump versions of the same two chipsets to be used for [[flip chip]] mounting, the preferred assembly technology in high-volume production.{{cite news|url=http://www.interconnectionworld.com/index/display/article-display/355756/articles/connector-specifier/industry-news/2009/03/iptronics-unveils-high-volume-flip-chip-solutions-for-40-120-gigabit-sec-apps.html|title=IPtronics unveils high volume 'flip chip' solutions for 40-, 120-Gigabit/sec apps|publisher=Interconnection World|date=March 10, 2009|accessdate=April 10, 2009}} Early 2010, IPtronics announced 16 Gbit/s versions of their 4- and 12-channel VCSEL drivers and TIAs.{{cite news|url=http://www.lightwaveonline.com/equipment-design/news/IPtronics-offers-silicon-for-16-Gbps-per-channel-parallel-optics--87006737.html|title=IPtronics offers silicon for 16-Gbps per channel parallel optics|publisher=[[LightWave]]|date=March 8, 2010|accessdate=March 9, 2010}}{{cite web |url=http://www.iptronics.com/37829/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-03-09 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110713053957/http://www.iptronics.com/37829/ |archivedate=2011-07-13 |df= }} The company announced in June 2010 it would address the market for "lower rates", especially driven by [[HDMI]] cables, at higher volumes, and a lower cost structure than active optical cables for InfiniBand.{{cite news|url=http://www.lightwaveonline.com/equipment-design/news/IPtronics-targets-low-cost-HDMI-with-parallel-optics-drivers-and-TIAs-96327159.html|title=IPtronics targets low-cost, HDMI with parallel news|url=http://www.design-reuse.com/news/21682/light-peak-intel-iptronics.html|title=IPtronics Develops Components for Light Peak Technology|publisher=D&R|date=October 1, 2009|accessdate=October 1, interconnect|last=Clarke|first=Peter|publisher=[[EETimes]]|date=October 1, 2009|accessdate=October 1, 2009}}{{cite news|url=http://news.cnet.com/8301-13924_3-10363956-64.html|title=Sources: 'Light Peak' technology not Apple idea|last=Crothers|first=Brooke|publisher=[[CNET News]]|date=September 29, 2009|accessdate=October 1, 2009}}{{cite news|url=http://iptronics.com/37753/|title=IPtronics 2009|accessdate=October 1, 2009}} IPtronics is a supplier of driver and receiver [[Integrated circuit|ICs]] that go into the optical module, performing the conversion from electricity to light and vice versa, using miniature [[lasers]] and [[photodetectors]]. The ICs from IPtronics are dual-channel, where each channel operates at a minimum of 10 Gbit/s. In October 2010, the company announced a new silicon revision.{{cite news|url=http://www.iptronics.com/37855/IPtronics%20Offers%20New%20Low%20Cost%20silicon%20/|title=IPtronics Offers New Low Cost silicon|publisher=IPtronics|date=October 2010|accessdate=November 22, 2010}} They claim the same cost competitiveness, enabling optical module and -cable applications such as Thunderbolt implementation, though now also single channel optical links up to 14 Gbit/s.
